**Bratislava** ,^[\[a\]](#cite_note-10)^ historically known as *Pozsony* and *Pressburg* ,^[\[b\]](#cite_note-11)^ is the [capital](/wiki/Capital_city "Capital city") and largest city of the [Slovak Republic](/wiki/Slovakia "Slovakia") and the fourth largest of all [cities on the River Danube](/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_on_the_Danube_river "List of cities and towns on the Danube river"). Officially, the population of the city is about 475,000; however, some sources estimate daily number of people moving around the city based on mobile phone [SIM cards](/wiki/SIM_cards "SIM cards") is more than 570,000.^[\[10\]](#cite_note-12)^ Bratislava is in southwestern Slovakia at the foot of the [Little Carpathians](/wiki/Little_Carpathians "Little Carpathians"), occupying both banks of the [River Danube](/wiki/River_Danube "River Danube") and the left bank of the [River Morava](/wiki/Morava_(river) "Morava (river)"). Bordering [Austria](/wiki/Austria "Austria") and [Hungary](/wiki/Hungary "Hungary"), it is the only national capital to border two [sovereign states](/wiki/Sovereign_states "Sovereign states").^[\[11\]](#cite_note-13)^{#cite_ref-13}

The city's history has been influenced by people of many nations and religions, including [Austrians](/wiki/Austrians "Austrians"), [Bulgarians](/wiki/Bulgarians "Bulgarians"), [Croats](/wiki/Croats "Croats"), [Czechs](/wiki/Czechs "Czechs"), [Germans](/wiki/Germans "Germans"), [Hungarians](/wiki/Hungarian_people "Hungarian people"), [Jews](/wiki/Jews "Jews") and [Slovaks](/wiki/Slovaks "Slovaks").^[\[12\]](#cite_note-culturebrochure-14)^ It was the coronation site and legislative center and capital of the [Kingdom of Hungary](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary "Kingdom of Hungary") from 1536 to 1783;^[\[13\]](#cite_note-NYT-15)^ eleven [Hungarian kings](/wiki/King_of_Hungary "King of Hungary") and eight queens were crowned in [St Martin's Cathedral](/wiki/St_Martin%27s_Cathedral,_Bratislava "St Martin's Cathedral, Bratislava"). Most [Hungarian parliament assemblies](/wiki/Diet_of_Hungary "Diet of Hungary") were held here from the 17th century until the [Hungarian Reform Era](/wiki/Hungarian_Reform_Era "Hungarian Reform Era"), and the city has been home to many Hungarian, German and Slovak historical figures.{#cite_ref-NYT_15-0}

Today, Bratislava is the [political](/wiki/Politics_of_Slovakia "Politics of Slovakia"), [cultural](/wiki/Culture_of_Slovakia "Culture of Slovakia") and [economic](/wiki/Economy_of_Slovakia "Economy of Slovakia") centre of Slovakia. It is the seat of the [Slovak president](/wiki/President_of_Slovakia "President of Slovakia"), the [parliament](/wiki/National_Council_of_the_Slovak_Republic "National Council of the Slovak Republic") and the [Slovak Executive](/wiki/Government_of_Slovakia "Government of Slovakia"). It has several universities, and many museums, theatres, galleries and other cultural and educational institutions.^[\[14\]](#cite_note-Welcomebrochure-16)^ Many large businesses and financial institutions have headquarters there. Bratislava is the 19th-richest region of the European Union by GDP ([PPP](/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity "Purchasing power parity")) per capita.^[\[15\]](#cite_note-17)^ GDP at purchasing power parity is about three times higher than in other Slovak regions.^[\[16\]](#cite_note-finweb.hnonline.sk-18)^^[\[17\]](#cite_note-19)^ The city receives around one million tourists every year, mostly from the Czech Republic, Germany, and Austria.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-20)^{#cite_ref-20}  

Etymology {#Etymology}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Etymology")\]

The medieval settlement *[Brezalauspurc](/wiki/Battle_of_Pressburg "Battle of Pressburg")* (literally, '[Braslav](/wiki/Braslav,_Duke_of_Lower_Pannonia "Braslav, Duke of Lower Pannonia")'s castle') was first mentioned in 907, is sometimes attributed to Bratislava, but the [actual location of Brezalauspurc](/wiki/Battle_of_Pressburg#Location "Battle of Pressburg") is under scholarly debate.

The name Pozsony was first mentioned in *Establishing charter of the abbey of Pannonhalma* \[[hu](https://hu.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pannonhalmi_alap%C3%ADt%C3%B3_oklev%C3%A9l "hu:Pannonhalmi alapító oklevél")\] in 1002. The linguist Ján Stanislav believed the city's Hungarian name, *Pozsony*, to be attributed to the surname Božan, likely a prince who owned the castle before 950. Although the Latin name was also based on the same surname, according to research by the lexicologist Milan Majtán, the Hungarian version is not found in any official records from the time in which the theorised prince would have lived. All three versions, however, were related to those found in Slovak, Czech and German: Vratislaburgum (905), Braslavespurch, and Preslavasburc (both 907).^[\[19\]](#cite_note-21)^ This however was disproved by János Melich, explaining that contemporary sources prove, that Bozan actually comes from a [germanisation](/wiki/Germanisation "Germanisation") by [Otto von Freising](/wiki/Otto_of_Freising "Otto of Freising") from the name Hungarian name *Poson,* along with another etymological theory claiming the name traces its origins to *Požúň* . He, similarly to historian Nandor Knauz claims, attesting that the popularity of the name of [Old Hungarian](/wiki/Old_Hungarian_language "Old Hungarian language") origin Poson in the era, that it is the personal name from which the cities name is derived^[\[20\]](#cite_note-22)^. Flóris Rómer and linguist Lajos Kiss also attributes the name Pozsony (originally spelled Posony) to the Hungarian name *Poson* , likely the first [ispán](/wiki/Isp%C3%A1n "Ispán") of the [castle](/wiki/Bratislava_Castle "Bratislava Castle").^[\[21\]](#cite_note-23)^^[\[22\]](#cite_note-24)^ The name then evolved to Praslavia, Praslaburck, and to Preßburg.^[\[23\]](#cite_note-25)^^[\[24\]](#cite_note-26)^{#cite_ref-26}

After [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"), during the [dissolution of Austria-Hungary](/wiki/Dissolution_of_Austria-Hungary "Dissolution of Austria-Hungary"), between the years 1918--1919, the name *Wilsonov* or *Wilsonstadt* was proposed by American Slovaks. The name was after President of the United States [Woodrow Wilson](/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson "Woodrow Wilson"), as he played a major role in the establishment of the new [First Czechoslovak Republic](/wiki/First_Czechoslovak_Republic "First Czechoslovak Republic").

The name *Bratislava* , which had been used only by some Slovak patriots, became official on 16 March 1919 with the aim that a Slavic name could support demands for the city to be part of Czechoslovakia.^[\[25\]](#cite_note-27)^^[\[26\]](#cite_note-28)^ Until then, it was *Pozsony* , mostly known in English as *Pressburg* (from its German name, *Preßburg*), since after 1526, it was dominated mostly by the Habsburg monarchy and the city had a relevant ethnic German population. That is the term from which the pre-1919 Slovak (*Prešporok*) and Czech (*Prešpurk*) names are derived.^[\[27\]](#cite_note-Czechreview-29)^{#cite_ref-Czechreview_29-0}

The city's modern name *Bratislava* is credited to [Pavol Jozef Šafárik](/wiki/Pavol_Jozef_%C5%A0af%C3%A1rik "Pavol Jozef Šafárik")'s misinterpretation of *Braslav* as *Bratislav* in his analysis of medieval sources, which led him to invent the term *Břetislaw* , which later became *Bratislav* .^[\[28\]](#cite_note-30)^{#cite_ref-30}

Other alternative names of the city in the past include [Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"): Ιστρόπολις, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Greek "Romanization of Greek"): *Istropolis* (meaning '[Danube](/wiki/Hister "Hister") City', also used in Latin), [Latin](/wiki/Latin_language "Latin language"): *Posonium* , [Romanian](/wiki/Romanian_language "Romanian language"): *Pojon* , [Croatian](/wiki/Croatian_language "Croatian language"): *Požun*.

In older documents, confusion can be caused by the Latin forms *Bratislavia, Wratislavia* etc., which refer to [Wrocław](/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw "Wrocław") (Breslau), Poland, not Bratislava. The Polish city has a similar etymology despite spelling differences.^[\[29\]](#cite_note-31)^{#cite_ref-31}  

History {#History}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: History")\]  
Main article: [History of Bratislava](/wiki/History_of_Bratislava "History of Bratislava")  
For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of Bratislava](/wiki/Timeline_of_Bratislava "Timeline of Bratislava").  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Boii_Biatec_1st._cen_BC_2940416.jpg/184px-Boii_Biatec_1st._cen_BC_2940416.jpg)](/wiki/File:Boii_Biatec_1st._cen_BC_2940416.jpg)  
[Biatec](/wiki/Biatec "Biatec"), presumably a king, who appeared on the Celtic coins minted by the [Boii](/wiki/Boii "Boii") at the current location of Bratislava, 1st century B.C.  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Gerulata.jpg/185px-Gerulata.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gerulata.jpg)  
[Gerulata](/wiki/Gerulata "Gerulata"), a [Roman Empire](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire") military camp, built in the 2nd century A.D. at the current location of Bratislava  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Peter_Johann_Nepomuk_Geiger_-_Battle_of_Pressburg.jpg/185px-Peter_Johann_Nepomuk_Geiger_-_Battle_of_Pressburg.jpg)](/wiki/File:Peter_Johann_Nepomuk_Geiger_-_Battle_of_Pressburg.jpg)  
[Battle of Bratislava](/wiki/Battle_of_Bratislava "Battle of Bratislava") in 907

The first known permanent settlement of the area began with the [Linear Pottery Culture](/wiki/Linear_Pottery_culture "Linear Pottery culture"), around 5000 B.C. in the [Neolithic](/wiki/Neolithic "Neolithic") era. About 200 B.C., the [Celtic](/wiki/Celts "Celts") [Boii](/wiki/Boii "Boii") tribe founded the first significant settlement, a fortified town known as an [oppidum](/wiki/Oppidum "Oppidum"). They also established a [mint](/wiki/Mint_(coin) "Mint (coin)"), producing gold and silver coins known as *[biatecs](/wiki/Biatec "Biatec")* .^[\[30\]](#cite_note-32)^{#cite_ref-32}

The area fell under [Roman](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire") influence from the 1st to the 4th century A.D. and was made part of the [Danubian Limes](/wiki/Danubian_Limes "Danubian Limes"), a border defence system.^[\[31\]](#cite_note-33)^ The Romans introduced [grape growing](/wiki/Viticulture "Viticulture") to the area and began a tradition of [winemaking](/wiki/Winemaking "Winemaking"), which survives to the present.^[\[32\]](#cite_note-34)^{#cite_ref-34}

The [Slavs](/wiki/Slavic_peoples "Slavic peoples") arrived from the East between the 5th and 6th centuries during the [Migration Period](/wiki/Migration_period "Migration period").^[\[33\]](#cite_note-35)^ As a response to onslaughts by [Avars](/wiki/Avars_(Carpathians) "Avars (Carpathians)"), the local Slavic tribes rebelled and established [Samo](/wiki/Samo "Samo")'s Empire (623--658), the first known Slavic political entity. In the 9th century, the castles at Bratislava *(Brezalauspurk)* and [Devín](/wiki/Dev%C3%ADn "Devín") *(Dowina)* were important centres of the Slavic states: the [Principality of Nitra](/wiki/Principality_of_Nitra "Principality of Nitra") and [Great Moravia](/wiki/Great_Moravia "Great Moravia").^[\[34\]](#cite_note-36)^ Scholars have debated the identification as fortresses of the two castles built in Great Moravia, based on linguistic arguments and because of the absence of convincing [archaeological](/wiki/Archaeological "Archaeological") evidence.^[\[35\]](#cite_note-Encyclopedia-37)^^[\[36\]](#cite_note-38)^{#cite_ref-38}

The first written reference to a settlement named "Brezalauspurc" dates to 907 and is related to the [Battle of Pressburg](/wiki/Battle_of_Pressburg "Battle of Pressburg"), during which a [Bavarian](/wiki/Bavaria "Bavaria") army was defeated by the [Hungarians](/wiki/Hungarian_people "Hungarian people"). It is connected to the fall of Great Moravia, already weakened by its own inner decline^[\[37\]](#cite_note-39)^ and under the attacks of the Hungarians.^[\[38\]](#cite_note-40)^ The exact location of the battle remains unknown, and some interpretations place it west of [Lake Balaton](/wiki/Lake_Balaton "Lake Balaton").^[\[39\]](#cite_note-41)^{#cite_ref-41}

In the 10th century, the territory of Pressburg (what would later become [Pozsony county](/wiki/Pozsony_County "Pozsony County")) became part of Hungary (called the "[Kingdom of Hungary](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary "Kingdom of Hungary")" from 1000). It developed as a key economic and administrative centre on the kingdom's frontier.^[\[40\]](#cite_note-middleages-42)^ In 1052, German Emperor [Henry III](/wiki/Henry_III,_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Henry III, Holy Roman Emperor") undertook a fifth campaign against the [Kingdom of Hungary](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary "Kingdom of Hungary"), and besieged Pressburg without success, as the Hungarians sank his supply ships on the [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube") river. This strategic position destined the city to be the site of frequent attacks and battles, but also brought it economic development and high political status. It was granted its first known "town privileges" in 1291 by the Hungarian [King Andrew III](/wiki/Andrew_III_of_Hungary "Andrew III of Hungary"),^[\[41\]](#cite_note-43)^ and was declared a [free royal town](/wiki/Free_royal_town "Free royal town") in 1405 by [King](/wiki/King_of_Hungary "King of Hungary") [Sigismund](/wiki/Sigismund,_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Sigismund, Holy Roman Emperor"). In 1436, he authorized the town to use its [own coat of arms](/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Bratislava "Coat of arms of Bratislava").^[\[42\]](#cite_note-44)^{#cite_ref-44}  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/K%C3%A9pes_kr%C3%B3nika_-_61.oldal_-_III._Henrik_cs%C3%A1sz%C3%A1r_haj%C3%B3inak_pusztul%C3%A1sa_Pozsonyn%C3%A1l.jpg/184px-K%C3%A9pes_kr%C3%B3nika_-_61.oldal_-_III._Henrik_cs%C3%A1sz%C3%A1r_haj%C3%B3inak_pusztul%C3%A1sa_Pozsonyn%C3%A1l.jpg)](/wiki/File:K%C3%A9pes_kr%C3%B3nika_-_61.oldal_-_III._Henrik_cs%C3%A1sz%C3%A1r_haj%C3%B3inak_pusztul%C3%A1sa_Pozsonyn%C3%A1l.jpg)  
The earliest known depiction of Pressburg Castle ([Chronicon Pictum](/wiki/Chronicon_Pictum "Chronicon Pictum"), 1358)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Bratislava_in_16th_century.jpg/185px-Bratislava_in_16th_century.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bratislava_in_16th_century.jpg)  
Pressburg (Bratislava) in 1588

The Kingdom of Hungary was defeated by the [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") in the [Battle of Mohács](/wiki/Battle_of_Moh%C3%A1cs "Battle of Mohács") in 1526. The Ottomans besieged and damaged Pressburg, but failed to conquer it.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-45)^ Owing to Ottoman advances into Hungarian territory, the city was designated the new capital of Hungary in 1536, after becoming part of the [Habsburg monarchy](/wiki/Habsburg_monarchy "Habsburg monarchy") and marking the beginning of a new era. The city became a coronation town and the seat of kings, archbishops (1543), the nobility and all major organisations and offices. Between 1536 and 1830, eleven Hungarian kings and queens were crowned at [St. Martin's Cathedral](/wiki/St._Martin%27s_Cathedral,_Bratislava "St. Martin's Cathedral, Bratislava").^[\[44\]](#cite_note-46)^{#cite_ref-46}

The 17th century was marked by anti-Habsburg uprisings, fighting with the Ottomans, floods, [plagues](/wiki/Bubonic_plague "Bubonic plague") and other disasters, which diminished the population.^[\[45\]](#cite_note-47)^ Great epidemics were spreading in Bratislava in 1541--1542, 1552--1553, 1660--1665 and 1678--1681. A [terrible outbreak](/wiki/Great_Plague_of_Vienna "Great Plague of Vienna") of 1678--1681 left approximately 11,000 casualties among Bratislava's residents (city population was in that time around 30,000 people). The last [plague outbreak](/wiki/Great_Northern_War_plague_outbreak "Great Northern War plague outbreak") of Bratislava was between the years 1712--1713.^[\[46\]](#cite_note-48)^{#cite_ref-48}

Pressburg flourished during the 18th-century reign of Queen [Maria Theresa](/wiki/Maria_Theresa_of_Austria "Maria Theresa of Austria"),^[\[47\]](#cite_note-NY-49)^ becoming the largest and most important town in the [Kingdom of Hungary](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary_(1526%E2%80%931867) "Kingdom of Hungary (1526–1867)").^[\[48\]](#cite_note-50)^ The population tripled; many new palaces,^[\[47\]](#cite_note-NY-49)^ monasteries, mansions, and streets were built, and the city was the centre of social and cultural life of the region.^[\[49\]](#cite_note-51)^ [Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart](/wiki/Wolfgang_Amadeus_Mozart "Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart") gave a concert in 1762 in the [Pálffy Palace](/wiki/P%C3%A1lffy_Palace_(Bratislava) "Pálffy Palace (Bratislava)"). [Joseph Haydn](/wiki/Joseph_Haydn "Joseph Haydn") performed in 1784 in the [Grassalkovich Palace](/wiki/Grassalkovich_Palace "Grassalkovich Palace"). [Ludwig van Beethoven](/wiki/Ludwig_van_Beethoven "Ludwig van Beethoven") was a guest in 1796 in the [Keglevich Palace](/wiki/Keglevich_Palace "Keglevich Palace").^[\[50\]](#cite_note-52)^^[\[51\]](#cite_note-53)^{#cite_ref-53}  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Bratislava_Slovakia_220.JPG/145px-Bratislava_Slovakia_220.JPG)](/wiki/File:Bratislava_Slovakia_220.JPG)  
The Plague Column built in 1713  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Maria_Theresa-coronation-1741-Pressburg-Hertz.jpg/200px-Maria_Theresa-coronation-1741-Pressburg-Hertz.jpg)](/wiki/File:Maria_Theresa-coronation-1741-Pressburg-Hertz.jpg)  
Coronation of [Maria Theresa](/wiki/Maria_Theresa "Maria Theresa") in 1741  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/C._Hirsch_d.J._-_Der_Kr%C3%B6nungsritt_Maria_Theresias_in_Pressburg_1747.jpg/101px-C._Hirsch_d.J._-_Der_Kr%C3%B6nungsritt_Maria_Theresias_in_Pressburg_1747.jpg)](/wiki/File:C._Hirsch_d.J._-_Der_Kr%C3%B6nungsritt_Maria_Theresias_in_Pressburg_1747.jpg)  
Maria Theresa's ride in Bratislava, 1747

The city started to lose its importance under the reign of Maria Theresa's son [Joseph II](/wiki/Joseph_II,_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor"),^[\[47\]](#cite_note-NY-49)^ especially after the [crown jewels](/wiki/Holy_Crown_of_Hungary "Holy Crown of Hungary") were taken to [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna") in 1783 in an attempt to strengthen the relations between Austria and Hungary. Many central offices subsequently moved to [Buda](/wiki/Buda "Buda"), followed by a large segment of the nobility.^[\[52\]](#cite_note-54)^ The first newspapers in Hungarian and Slovak were published here: *Magyar hírmondó* in 1780, and *Presspurske Nowiny* in 1783.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-55)^ In the course of the 18th century, the city became a centre for the [Slovak national movement](/wiki/History_of_Slovakia#Slovak_National_Movement "History of Slovakia").^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-55}

The city's 19th-century history was closely tied to the major events in Europe. The [Peace of Pressburg](/wiki/Peace_of_Pressburg_(1805) "Peace of Pressburg (1805)") between the [Austrian Empire](/wiki/Austrian_Empire "Austrian Empire") and [French Empire](/wiki/First_French_Empire "First French Empire") was signed here in 1805.^[\[54\]](#cite_note-56)^ [Devín Castle](/wiki/Dev%C3%ADn_Castle "Devín Castle") was ruined by [Napoleon](/wiki/Napoleon_I "Napoleon I")'s French troops during an invasion of 1809.^[\[55\]](#cite_note-57)^ In 1825 the [Hungarian National Learned Society](/wiki/Hungarian_Academy_of_Sciences "Hungarian Academy of Sciences") (the present Hungarian Academy of Sciences) was founded in Pressburg using a donation from [István Széchenyi](/wiki/Istv%C3%A1n_Sz%C3%A9chenyi "István Széchenyi"). In 1843 Hungarian was proclaimed the official language in legislation, public administration, and education by the Diet in the city.^[\[56\]](#cite_note-58)^{#cite_ref-58}  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Josef_Holzer_Blick_auf_die_Burgruine_Devin_1864.jpg/200px-Josef_Holzer_Blick_auf_die_Burgruine_Devin_1864.jpg)](/wiki/File:Josef_Holzer_Blick_auf_die_Burgruine_Devin_1864.jpg)  
[Devín Castle](/wiki/Dev%C3%ADn_Castle "Devín Castle"), in 1809 [Napoleon Bonaparte](/wiki/Napoleon "Napoleon")'s French army blew up the castle  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Bratislava_Castle_destroyed_by_fire%2C_1811.jpg/200px-Bratislava_Castle_destroyed_by_fire%2C_1811.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bratislava_Castle_destroyed_by_fire,_1811.jpg)  
In 1811, a huge fire raged through [Bratislava Castle](/wiki/Bratislava_Castle "Bratislava Castle"), destroyed the main palace and more than 70 nearby houses  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Pozsony.jpg/200px-Pozsony.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pozsony.jpg)  
Pressburg (Bratislava) in the 19th century

As a reaction to the [Revolutions of 1848](/wiki/Hungarian_Revolution_of_1848 "Hungarian Revolution of 1848"), [Ferdinand V](/wiki/Ferdinand_I_of_Austria "Ferdinand I of Austria") signed the so-called [April laws](/wiki/April_laws "April laws"), which included the abolition of [serfdom](/wiki/Serfdom "Serfdom"), at the [Primate's Palace](/wiki/Primate%27s_Palace,_Bratislava "Primate's Palace, Bratislava").^[\[57\]](#cite_note-Napoleon-59)^ The city chose the revolutionary Hungarian side, but was captured by the Austrians in December 1848.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-60)^{#cite_ref-60}

Industry developed rapidly in the 19th century. The first [horse-drawn railway](/wiki/Horsecar "Horsecar") in the Kingdom of Hungary,^[\[59\]](#cite_note-61)^ from Pressburg to Szentgyörgy ([Svätý Jur](/wiki/Sv%C3%A4t%C3%BD_Jur "Svätý Jur")), was built in 1840.^[\[60\]](#cite_note-62)^ A new line to Vienna using [steam locomotives](/wiki/Steam_locomotive "Steam locomotive") was opened in 1848, and a line to [Pest](/wiki/Pest,_Hungary "Pest, Hungary") in 1850.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-63)^ Many new industrial, financial and other institutions were founded; for example, the first bank in present-day Slovakia was founded in 1842.^[\[62\]](#cite_note-64)^ The city's first permanent bridge over the Danube, [Starý most](/wiki/Star%C3%BD_most_(Bratislava) "Starý most (Bratislava)") (Old Bridge), was built in 1891.^[\[63\]](#cite_note-65)^ Between the years 1867-1918, the territory of Pressburg became part of [Austro-Hungarian Empire](/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Empire "Austro-Hungarian Empire").{#cite_ref-65}

Before [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"), the city had a population that was 42% German, 41% Hungarian and 15% Slovak (1910 census). The first post war census in 1919 declared the city's ethnic composition at 36% German, 33% Slovak and 29% Hungarian but this may have reflected changing self-identification, rather than an exchange of peoples. Many people were bi- or trilingual and multicultural.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

After [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"), the [dissolution of the Austro-Hungarian Empire](/wiki/Dissolution_of_Austria-Hungary "Dissolution of Austria-Hungary") began. U.S. president [Woodrow Wilson](/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson "Woodrow Wilson") and the United States played a major role in the establishment of the new [Czechoslovak state](/wiki/First_Czechoslovak_Republic "First Czechoslovak Republic"). American Slovaks proposed rename the city "Wilsonovo mesto" (Wilson City), after Woodrow Wilson.^[\[64\]](#cite_note-66)^{#cite_ref-66}

On 28 October 1918, [Czechoslovakia](/wiki/First_Czechoslovak_Republic "First Czechoslovak Republic") was proclaimed, but its borders were not settled for several months.^[\[65\]](#cite_note-:1-67)^ The dominant Hungarian and German population tried to prevent annexation of the city to Czechoslovakia and declared it a [free city](/wiki/Royal_free_city "Royal free city"),^[\[66\]](#cite_note-peyqxj-68)^ while the Hungarian Prime Minister Károlyi protested against the Czech invasion. The Slovak National Assembly meanwhile called it a *"defensive action of the Slovaks themselves, to end the anarchy caused by the flight of the Hungarians."* ^[\[67\]](#cite_note-69)^ The [Allies of World War I](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I "Allies of World War I") drew a provisional demarcation line, this was revealed to the Hungarian government on December 23, in the document known as the [Vix Note](/wiki/Vix_Note "Vix Note"). The [Czechoslovak Legion](/wiki/Czechoslovak_Legion "Czechoslovak Legion") arrived from Italy, began to advance on 30 December and by 2 January 1919, all important civil and military buildings were in Czechoslovak hands.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-70)^ It was the beginning of the conflict, which later continued as the [Hungarian--Czechoslovak War](/wiki/Hungarian%E2%80%93Czechoslovak_War "Hungarian–Czechoslovak War"). The city became the seat of Slovakia's political organs and organizations and became Slovakia's capital on 4 February.^[\[69\]](#cite_note-71)^{#cite_ref-71}  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Duna-part._Fortepan_9282.jpg/200px-Duna-part._Fortepan_9282.jpg)](/wiki/File:Duna-part._Fortepan_9282.jpg)  
Pressburg (Bratislava) in 1915 during [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Czechoslovak_Legion_in_Bratislava%2C_1919.png/200px-Czechoslovak_Legion_in_Bratislava%2C_1919.png)](/wiki/File:Czechoslovak_Legion_in_Bratislava,_1919.png)  
[Czechoslovak Legion](/wiki/Czechoslovak_Legion "Czechoslovak Legion") at the [Old Bridge](/wiki/Star%C3%BD_most_(Bratislava) "Starý most (Bratislava)") (Starý most) in Bratislava during [Hungarian--Czechoslovak War](/wiki/Hungarian%E2%80%93Czechoslovak_War "Hungarian–Czechoslovak War"), 1919

On March 27, 1919, the name Bratislava was officially adopted for the first time to replace the previous Slovak name Prešporok.^[\[70\]](#cite_note-72)^{#cite_ref-72}

At the beginning of August 1919, Czechoslovakia got permission to correct the borders for the strategic reasons, mainly to secure the port and to prevent a potential attack of the [Hungarian Army](/wiki/Hungarian_Army "Hungarian Army") on the town. On the night of 14 August 1919 barefoot Czechoslovak soldiers silently climbed to the Hungarian side of the [Starý most](/wiki/Star%C3%BD_most_(Bratislava) "Starý most (Bratislava)") (Old Bridge), captured the guards and annexed [Petržalka](/wiki/Petr%C5%BEalka "Petržalka") (currently part of Bratislava's [5th district](/wiki/Bratislava_5 "Bratislava 5")) without a fight.^[\[71\]](#cite_note-73)^ The [Paris Peace Conference](/wiki/Paris_Peace_Conference,_1919 "Paris Peace Conference, 1919") assigned the area to [Czechoslovakia](/wiki/First_Czechoslovak_Republic "First Czechoslovak Republic") with the aim of creating a [bridgehead](/wiki/Bridgehead "Bridgehead") for the newly created Czechoslovak state for controlling the Danube.{#cite_ref-73}

Left without any protection after the retreat of the Hungarian army, many Hungarians were expelled or fled.^[\[72\]](#cite_note-74)^ Czechs and Slovaks moved their households to Bratislava. Education in [Hungarian](/wiki/Culture_of_Hungary "Culture of Hungary") and [German](/wiki/German_language_in_Europe "German language in Europe") was radically reduced in the city.^[\[73\]](#cite_note-75)^ By the 1930 [Czechoslovak](/wiki/Czechoslovakia "Czechoslovakia") [census](/wiki/Census "Census"), the Hungarian population of Bratislava had decreased to 15.8% (see the [Demographics of Bratislava](/wiki/Demographics_of_Bratislava "Demographics of Bratislava") article for more details).{#cite_ref-75}

In 1938, [Nazi Germany](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany") annexed neighbouring Austria in the [Anschluss](/wiki/Anschluss "Anschluss"); on 10 October 1938 on the basis of the [Munich Agreement](/wiki/Munich_Agreement "Munich Agreement") it also annexed (still-separate from Bratislava) [Petržalka](/wiki/Petr%C5%BEalka "Petržalka") and [Devín](/wiki/Dev%C3%ADn "Devín") boroughs on ethnic grounds, as these had many ethnic Germans.^[\[74\]](#cite_note-WWII-76)^^[\[75\]](#cite_note-77)^ Petržalka was renamed as *Engerau* and Devín was renamed as *Theben an der March* . The [Starý most](/wiki/Star%C3%BD_most_(Bratislava) "Starý most (Bratislava)") (Old Bridge) became a border bridge between [Czechoslovakia](/wiki/Second_Czechoslovak_Republic "Second Czechoslovak Republic") and Nazi Germany.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-77}  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Adolf_Hitler_in_Bratislava%2C_1938.webp/200px-Adolf_Hitler_in_Bratislava%2C_1938.webp.png)](/wiki/File:Adolf_Hitler_in_Bratislava,_1938.webp)  
German [Führer](/wiki/F%C3%BChrer "Führer") [Adolf Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler "Adolf Hitler") on his visit to Bratislava after [Munich Betrayal](/wiki/Munich_agreement "Munich agreement"), October 1938  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/B-24_Liberators_over_Bratislava%2C_Slovakia_on_16_June_1944.jpg/200px-B-24_Liberators_over_Bratislava%2C_Slovakia_on_16_June_1944.jpg)](/wiki/File:B-24_Liberators_over_Bratislava,_Slovakia_on_16_June_1944.jpg)  
Bratislava was bombarded by the [United States Army Air Forces](/wiki/United_States_Army_Air_Forces "United States Army Air Forces"), during the [Nazi](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany") occupation in 1944

Bratislava was declared the capital of the [first independent Slovak Republic](/wiki/Slovak_Republic_(1939%E2%80%931945) "Slovak Republic (1939–1945)") on March 14, 1939, but the new state quickly fell under Nazi influence. In 1941--1942 and 1944--1945, the new Slovak government cooperated in deporting most of Bratislava's approximately 15,000 Jews;^[\[76\]](#cite_note-78)^ they were transported to [concentration camps](/wiki/Internment "Internment"), where most were killed or died before the end of the war in the [Holocaust](/wiki/Holocaust "Holocaust").^[\[77\]](#cite_note-post-war-79)^{#cite_ref-post-war_79-0}

Bratislava, occupied by German troops, was many times bombarded by the [Allies](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War II"). Major air raid included the bombing of Bratislava and its refinery [Apollo](/wiki/Slovnaft "Slovnaft") on June 16, 1944 by American [B-24 bombers](/wiki/Consolidated_B-24_Liberator "Consolidated B-24 Liberator") of the [Fifteenth Air Force](/wiki/Fifteenth_Air_Force#World_War_II "Fifteenth Air Force") with 181 victims^[\[78\]](#cite_note-80)^ [Bombardment group](/wiki/Bombardment_group "Bombardment group") attacked in four waves with overall 158 planes. On 4 April 1945, Bratislava was liberated by the [Soviet Red Army](/wiki/Red_Army "Red Army") [2nd Ukrainian Front](/wiki/2nd_Ukrainian_Front "2nd Ukrainian Front") during the [Bratislava--Brno offensive](/wiki/Bratislava%E2%80%93Brno_offensive "Bratislava–Brno offensive").^[\[74\]](#cite_note-WWII-76)^^[\[79\]](#cite_note-81)^ The [Czechoslovak government](/wiki/Czechoslovak_Republic_(1945%E2%80%9348)#1945 "Czechoslovak Republic (1945–48)") and president [Edvard Beneš](/wiki/Edvard_Bene%C5%A1 "Edvard Beneš") then moved to Bratislava on 8 May.^[\[80\]](#cite_note-82)^{#cite_ref-82}

At the end of World War II, most of Bratislava's ethnic Germans were evacuated by the German authorities. A few returned after the war, but were soon expelled without their properties under the [Beneš decrees](/wiki/Bene%C5%A1_decrees "Beneš decrees"),^[\[81\]](#cite_note-83)^ part of a widespread [expulsion of ethnic Germans](/wiki/Expulsion_of_Germans_from_Czechoslovakia "Expulsion of Germans from Czechoslovakia") from eastern Europe.{#cite_ref-83}

After World War II, [Slovak Republic](/wiki/Slovak_Republic_(1939%E2%80%931945) "Slovak Republic (1939–1945)") lost its so-called independence and was reunified again with the Czech Republic as [Czechoslovak Republic](/wiki/Third_Czechoslovak_Republic "Third Czechoslovak Republic"). [Engerau](/wiki/Petr%C5%BEalka "Petržalka") (currently part of Bratislava's [5th district](/wiki/Bratislava_5 "Bratislava 5")) and [Theben an der March](/wiki/Dev%C3%ADn "Devín") (currently part of Bratislava's [4th district](/wiki/Bratislava_5 "Bratislava 5")) was returned to Czechoslovakia and renamed back as Petržalka and Devín. Furthermore, after signing the [Peace Treaty of Paris](/wiki/Paris_Peace_Treaties,_1947 "Paris Peace Treaties, 1947") on 10 February 1947, three [Hungarian](/wiki/Hungary "Hungary") villages, namely [Horvátjárfalu](/wiki/Jarovce "Jarovce") (Jarovce), [Oroszvár](/wiki/Rusovce "Rusovce") (Rusovce), and [Dunacsún](/wiki/%C4%8Cunovo "Čunovo") (Čunovo) situated south of Bratislava were transferred to Czechoslovakia, in order to form the so-called "[Bratislava bridgehead](/wiki/Bratislava_bridgehead "Bratislava bridgehead")" (currently all three of them are part of Bratislava's [5th district](/wiki/Bratislava_5 "Bratislava 5")).

After the [Communist Party](/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Czechoslovakia "Communist Party of Czechoslovakia") seized power in [Czechoslovakia](/wiki/Czechoslovak_Socialist_Republic "Czechoslovak Socialist Republic") in February 1948, the city became part of the [Eastern Bloc](/wiki/Eastern_Bloc "Eastern Bloc"). The city annexed new land, and the population rose significantly, becoming 90% Slovak.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Bratislava_1968_2.jpg/205px-Bratislava_1968_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bratislava_1968_2.jpg)  
[Soviet](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") tank in Bratislava during the [Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia](/wiki/Warsaw_Pact_invasion_of_Czechoslovakia "Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia") in 1968  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Memorial_of_Iron_Curtain%2C_Bratislava%2C_20220428_1104_5796.jpg/205px-Memorial_of_Iron_Curtain%2C_Bratislava%2C_20220428_1104_5796.jpg)](/wiki/File:Memorial_of_Iron_Curtain,_Bratislava,_20220428_1104_5796.jpg)  
[Iron Curtain](/wiki/Iron_Curtain "Iron Curtain") memorial in Bratislava, 400 people were killed trying to cross the border into the West during the communist era

Large residential areas consisting of high-rise [prefabricated](/wiki/Prefabrication "Prefabrication") [panel buildings](/wiki/Panel%C3%A1k "Panelák"), such as those in the [Petržalka](/wiki/Petr%C5%BEalka "Petržalka") or [Dúbravka](/wiki/D%C3%BAbravka,_Bratislava "Dúbravka, Bratislava") borough, were built. The Communist government also built several new grandiose buildings, such as the [Slovak Radio Building](/wiki/Slovak_Radio_Building "Slovak Radio Building"), [Slavín](/wiki/Slav%C3%ADn "Slavín") or [Kamzík TV Tower](/wiki/Kamz%C3%ADk_TV_Tower "Kamzík TV Tower"). A quarter of Bratislava's [Old Town](/wiki/Old_Town,_Bratislava "Old Town, Bratislava") was demolished in the late 1960s for a single project: [the bridge of the Slovak National Uprising](/wiki/Most_SNP "Most SNP"). To make space for this development, much of the city's centuries-old, historical Jewish quarter was razed, including the 19th-century Moorish-styled Neolog Synagogue.^[\[82\]](#cite_note-84)^{#cite_ref-84}

In 1968, after the unsuccessful [Czechoslovak attempt](/wiki/Prague_Spring "Prague Spring") to liberalise the Communist regime, the city was occupied by [Warsaw Pact](/wiki/Warsaw_Pact "Warsaw Pact") troops. Shortly thereafter, it became capital of the [Slovak Socialist Republic](/wiki/Slovak_Socialist_Republic "Slovak Socialist Republic"), one of the two states of the [federalized](/wiki/Constitutional_Act_on_the_Czechoslovak_Federation "Constitutional Act on the Czechoslovak Federation") [Czechoslovakia](/wiki/Czechoslovak_Socialist_Republic "Czechoslovak Socialist Republic").

Bratislava's dissidents anticipated the fall of Communism with the [Bratislava candle demonstration](/wiki/Candle_demonstration_in_Bratislava "Candle demonstration in Bratislava") in 1988, and the city became one of the foremost centres of the anti-Communist [Velvet Revolution](/wiki/Velvet_Revolution "Velvet Revolution") in 1989.^[\[83\]](#cite_note-85)^{#cite_ref-85}

The end of Communist rule in Czechoslovakia in 1989 was followed once again by the country's dissolution, this time into two [successor states](/wiki/Succession_of_states "Succession of states"). [Czechoslovak Socialist Republic](/wiki/Czechoslovak_Socialist_Republic "Czechoslovak Socialist Republic") renamed as [Czech and Slovak Federative Republic](/wiki/Czech_and_Slovak_Federative_Republic "Czech and Slovak Federative Republic"), the word "socialist" was dropped in the names of the two republics within the federation, the Slovak Socialist Republic renamed as the [Slovak Republic](/wiki/Slovak_Socialist_Republic "Slovak Socialist Republic").

In 1993, Bratislava once again became the capital of the newly formed independent [Slovak Republic](/wiki/Slovak_Republic "Slovak Republic"), following the [Velvet Divorce](/wiki/Dissolution_of_Czechoslovakia "Dissolution of Czechoslovakia").^[\[84\]](#cite_note-86)^{#cite_ref-86}  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Geography")\]  
Main article: [Geography of Bratislava](/wiki/Geography_of_Bratislava "Geography of Bratislava")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/OSM.Bratislava.2009-08-21.png/220px-OSM.Bratislava.2009-08-21.png)](/wiki/File:OSM.Bratislava.2009-08-21.png) Map of Bratislava [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Bratislava%2C_Slovakia_Astronaut_Imagery.JPG/220px-Bratislava%2C_Slovakia_Astronaut_Imagery.JPG)](/wiki/File:Bratislava,_Slovakia_Astronaut_Imagery.JPG) Satellite view of Bratislava

Bratislava is situated in southwestern Slovakia, within the [Bratislava Region](/wiki/Bratislava_Region "Bratislava Region"). Its location on the borders with Austria and Hungary makes it the [only national capital that borders two countries](/wiki/List_of_national_capitals_situated_on_an_international_border "List of national capitals situated on an international border"). It is only 18 kilometres (11.2 mi) from the border with Hungary and only 60 kilometres (37.3 mi) from the Austrian capital [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna").^[\[85\]](#cite_note-87)^{#cite_ref-87}

The city has a total area of 367.58 square kilometres (141.9 sq mi), making it the second-largest city in Slovakia by area (after the township of [Vysoké Tatry](/wiki/Vysok%C3%A9_Tatry_(town) "Vysoké Tatry (town)")).^[\[86\]](#cite_note-88)^ Bratislava straddles the [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube") River, along which it had developed and for centuries the chief transportation route to other areas. The river passes through the city from the west to the southeast. The [Middle Danube](/wiki/Middle_Danube "Middle Danube") basin begins at [Devín Gate](/wiki/Dev%C3%ADn_Gate "Devín Gate") in western Bratislava. Other rivers are the [Morava River](/wiki/Morava_(river) "Morava (river)"), which forms the northwestern border of the city and enters the Danube at Devín, the [Little Danube](/wiki/Little_Danube "Little Danube"), and the [Vydrica](/wiki/Vydrica_(river) "Vydrica (river)"), which enters the Danube in the borough of [Karlova Ves](/wiki/Karlova_Ves "Karlova Ves").{#cite_ref-88}

The [Carpathian](/wiki/Carpathian_Mountains "Carpathian Mountains") mountain range begins in city territory with the [Little Carpathians](/wiki/Little_Carpathians "Little Carpathians") (*Malé Karpaty* ). The [Záhorie](/wiki/Z%C3%A1horie "Záhorie") and [Danubian](/wiki/Danubian_Lowland "Danubian Lowland") lowlands stretch into Bratislava. The city's lowest point is at the Danube's surface at 126 metres (413 ft) [above mean sea level](/wiki/Above_mean_sea_level "Above mean sea level"), and the highest point is [Devínska Kobyla](/wiki/Dev%C3%ADnska_Kobyla "Devínska Kobyla") at 514 metres (1,686 ft). The average altitude is 140 metres (460 ft).^[\[87\]](#cite_note-89)^{#cite_ref-89}  

### Climate {#Climate}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Climate")\]

Bratislava has recently shifted into the [humid subtropical climate](/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate "Humid subtropical climate") under [Köppen--Geiger climate classification](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification") (*[Cfa](/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate "Humid subtropical climate")* ), closely bordering on *Dfa* , and is classified as temperate oceanic climate under [Trewartha climate classification](/wiki/Trewartha_climate_classification "Trewartha climate classification") (*Doak* ), It is in USDA [Plant Hardiness Zone](/wiki/Hardiness_zone "Hardiness zone") 7b^[\[88\]](#cite_note-90)^ with a mean annual temperature of around 11.1 °C (52.0 °F), an average temperature of 22.0 °C (71.6 °F) in the warmest month and 0.3 °C (32.5 °F) in the coldest month, four distinct seasons^[\[89\]](#cite_note-Bratislava_Weather-91)^ and precipitation spread rather evenly throughout the year. It is often windy with a marked variation between hot summers and cold, humid winters. There also can sometimes be a significant difference in weather, between the parts of the city. Bratislava, just like any other city, has an [urban heat island](/wiki/Urban_heat_island "Urban heat island") effect, but there is no weather station directly in the urban core, so the temperature there can be slightly higher than the official weather station reports. The city is in one of the warmest and driest parts of Slovakia.^[\[90\]](#cite_note-92)^{#cite_ref-92}

Recently, the transitions from winter to summer and summer to winter have been rapid, with short autumn and spring periods. Snow occurs less frequently than previously.^[\[89\]](#cite_note-Bratislava_Weather-91)^ Extreme temperatures (1981--2013) -- record high: 39.4 °C (102.9 °F),^[\[91\]](#cite_note-93)^ record low: −24.6 °C (−12.3 °F). Some areas, particularly Devín and [Devínska Nová Ves](/wiki/Dev%C3%ADnska_Nov%C3%A1_Ves "Devínska Nová Ves"), are vulnerable to floods from the Danube and Morava rivers.^[\[92\]](#cite_note-94)^ New flood protection has been built on both banks.^[\[93\]](#cite_note-95)^{#cite_ref-95}

Cityscape and architecture {#Cityscape_and_architecture}
--------------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Cityscape and architecture")\]  
See also: [List of palaces in Bratislava](/wiki/List_of_palaces_in_Bratislava "List of palaces in Bratislava")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Hviezdoslavovo_n%C3%A1mestie_%2810266936594%29.jpg/195px-Hviezdoslavovo_n%C3%A1mestie_%2810266936594%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hviezdoslavovo_n%C3%A1mestie_(10266936594).jpg)  
[Hviezdoslav Square](/wiki/Hviezdoslavovo_n%C3%A1mestie_(Bratislava) "Hviezdoslavovo námestie (Bratislava)")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Hlavn%C3%A9_n%C3%A1mestie-The_napoleonic_soldier%2C_Old_Town_Hall_and_Roland_Fountain-Bratislava.JPG/195px-Hlavn%C3%A9_n%C3%A1mestie-The_napoleonic_soldier%2C_Old_Town_Hall_and_Roland_Fountain-Bratislava.JPG)](/wiki/File:Hlavn%C3%A9_n%C3%A1mestie-The_napoleonic_soldier,_Old_Town_Hall_and_Roland_Fountain-Bratislava.JPG)  
[Main Square](/wiki/Hlavn%C3%A9_n%C3%A1mestie_(Bratislava) "Hlavné námestie (Bratislava)")

The cityscape of Bratislava is characterized by medieval towers and grandiose 20th-century buildings, but it underwent profound changes in a construction boom at the start of the 21st century.^[\[97\]](#cite_note-habsudova-99)^{#cite_ref-habsudova_99-0}

Most historical buildings are concentrated in the [Old Town](/wiki/Old_Town,_Bratislava "Old Town, Bratislava"). [Bratislava's Town Hall](/wiki/Old_Town_Hall_(Bratislava) "Old Town Hall (Bratislava)") is a complex of three buildings erected in the 14th--15th centuries and now hosts the [Bratislava City Museum](/wiki/Bratislava_City_Museum "Bratislava City Museum"). [Michael's Gate](/wiki/Michael%27s_Gate "Michael's Gate") is the only gate that has been preserved from the [medieval fortifications](/wiki/Bratislava_Fortifications "Bratislava Fortifications"), and it ranks among the oldest of the town's buildings;^[\[98\]](#cite_note-100)^ the narrowest house in Europe is nearby.^[\[99\]](#cite_note-101)^ The University Library building, erected in 1756, was used by the [Diet of the Kingdom of Hungary](/wiki/Diet_of_Hungary "Diet of Hungary") from 1802 to 1848.^[\[100\]](#cite_note-unilibrary-102)^ Much of the significant legislation of the [Hungarian Reform Era](/wiki/Hungarian_Reform_Era "Hungarian Reform Era") (such as the abolition of [serfdom](/wiki/Serfdom "Serfdom") and the foundation of the [Hungarian Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Hungarian_Academy_of_Sciences "Hungarian Academy of Sciences")) was enacted there.^[\[100\]](#cite_note-unilibrary-102)^{#cite_ref-unilibrary_102-1}

The historic centre is characterized by many [baroque](/wiki/Baroque "Baroque") palaces. The [Grassalkovich Palace](/wiki/Grassalkovich_Palace "Grassalkovich Palace"), built around 1760, is now the residence of the Slovak president, and the Slovak government now has its seat in the former [Archiepiscopal Palace](/wiki/Summer_Archbishop%27s_Palace "Summer Archbishop's Palace").^[\[101\]](#cite_note-103)^ In 1805, diplomats of emperors [Napoleon](/wiki/Napoleon_I "Napoleon I") and [Francis II](/wiki/Francis_II,_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Francis II, Holy Roman Emperor") signed the fourth [Peace of Pressburg](/wiki/Peace_of_Pressburg_(1805) "Peace of Pressburg (1805)") in the [Primate's Palace](/wiki/Primate%27s_Palace,_Bratislava "Primate's Palace, Bratislava"), after Napoleon's victory in the [Battle of Austerlitz](/wiki/Battle_of_Austerlitz "Battle of Austerlitz").^[\[102\]](#cite_note-104)^ Some smaller houses are historically significant; composer [Johann Nepomuk Hummel](/wiki/Johann_Nepomuk_Hummel "Johann Nepomuk Hummel") was born in an 18th-century house in the Old Town.{#cite_ref-104}  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Bratislava_-_Katedr%C3%A1la_sv%C3%A4t%C3%A9ho_Martina_20180510-03.jpg/135px-Bratislava_-_Katedr%C3%A1la_sv%C3%A4t%C3%A9ho_Martina_20180510-03.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bratislava_-_Katedr%C3%A1la_sv%C3%A4t%C3%A9ho_Martina_20180510-03.jpg)  
[St. Martin's Cathedral](/wiki/St._Martin%27s_Cathedral,_Bratislava "St. Martin's Cathedral, Bratislava")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Ko%C5%9Bci%C3%B3%C5%82_%C5%9Awi%C4%99tej_El%C5%BCbiety_w_Bratys%C5%82awie%2C_20210727_1251_0364.jpg/170px-Ko%C5%9Bci%C3%B3%C5%82_%C5%9Awi%C4%99tej_El%C5%BCbiety_w_Bratys%C5%82awie%2C_20210727_1251_0364.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ko%C5%9Bci%C3%B3%C5%82_%C5%9Awi%C4%99tej_El%C5%BCbiety_w_Bratys%C5%82awie,_20210727_1251_0364.jpg)  
[Church of St. Elisabeth](/wiki/Church_of_St._Elisabeth,_Bratislava "Church of St. Elisabeth, Bratislava")

Notable cathedrals and churches include the [Gothic](/wiki/Gothic_architecture "Gothic architecture") [St. Martin's Cathedral](/wiki/St._Martin%27s_Cathedral,_Bratislava "St. Martin's Cathedral, Bratislava") built in the 13th--16th centuries, which served as the coronation church of the Kingdom of Hungary between 1536 and 1830.^[\[103\]](#cite_note-cathedral-105)^ The [Franciscan Church](/wiki/Franciscan_Church_(Bratislava) "Franciscan Church (Bratislava)"), dating to the 13th century, has been a place of knighting ceremonies and is the oldest preserved sacral building in the city.^[\[104\]](#cite_note-106)^ The [Church of St. Elizabeth](/wiki/Church_of_St._Elisabeth_(Bratislava) "Church of St. Elisabeth (Bratislava)"), better known as the Blue Church due to its colour, is built entirely in the [Hungarian Secessionist](/wiki/Art_Nouveau "Art Nouveau") style. Bratislava has one surviving functioning [synagogue](/wiki/Heydukova_Street_Synagogue "Heydukova Street Synagogue"), out of the three major ones existing before the [holocaust](/wiki/Holocaust "Holocaust").{#cite_ref-106}

A curiosity is the underground (formerly ground-level) restored portion of the Jewish cemetery where 19th-century Rabbi [Moses Sofer](/wiki/Moses_Sofer "Moses Sofer") is buried, located at the base of the castle hill near the entrance to a tram tunnel.^[\[105\]](#cite_note-107)^ The only military cemetery in Bratislava is [Slavín](/wiki/Slav%C3%ADn "Slavín"), unveiled in 1960 in honour of [Soviet Army](/wiki/Red_Army "Red Army") soldiers who fell during the liberation of Bratislava in April 1945. It offers a view of the city and the [Little Carpathians](/wiki/Little_Carpathians "Little Carpathians").^[\[106\]](#cite_note-108)^^[\[107\]](#cite_note-109)^{#cite_ref-109}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Ko%C5%9Bci%C3%B3%C5%82_franciszka%C5%84ski_Zwiastowania_Pa%C5%84skiego_w_Bratys%C5%82awie%2C_20210727_1313_0383.jpg/220px-Ko%C5%9Bci%C3%B3%C5%82_franciszka%C5%84ski_Zwiastowania_Pa%C5%84skiego_w_Bratys%C5%82awie%2C_20210727_1313_0383.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ko%C5%9Bci%C3%B3%C5%82_franciszka%C5%84ski_Zwiastowania_Pa%C5%84skiego_w_Bratys%C5%82awie,_20210727_1313_0383.jpg) Franciscan Church and Monastery with the tall gothic tower was built in the late 13th century. The oldest building in Bratislava.

Other prominent 20th-century structures include the [Most Slovenského národného povstania](/wiki/Most_Slovensk%C3%A9ho_n%C3%A1rodn%C3%A9ho_povstania "Most Slovenského národného povstania") (Bridge of the Slovak national uprising) across the [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube") featuring a [UFO](/wiki/Unidentified_flying_object "Unidentified flying object")-like [tower restaurant](/wiki/UFO_(restaurant) "UFO (restaurant)"), [Slovak Radio](/wiki/Slovensk%C3%BD_rozhlas "Slovenský rozhlas")'s inverted-pyramid-shaped headquarters, and the uniquely designed [Kamzík TV Tower](/wiki/Kamz%C3%ADk_TV_Tower "Kamzík TV Tower") with an observation deck and rotating restaurant. In the early 21st century, new edifices have transformed the traditional cityscape. At the beginning of the 21st century, a construction boom has spawned new public structures,^[\[108\]](#cite_note-realestate-110)^ such as the [Most Apollo](/wiki/Apollo_Bridge "Apollo Bridge") and a new building of the [Slovak National Theatre](/wiki/Slovak_National_Theatre "Slovak National Theatre"),^[\[109\]](#cite_note-liptakova-111)^ as well as private [real-estate development](/wiki/Real_estate_development "Real estate development").^[\[110\]](#cite_note-nahalkova-112)^{#cite_ref-nahalkova_112-0}  

### Bratislava Castle {#Bratislava_Castle}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Bratislava Castle")\]  
Main article: [Bratislava Castle](/wiki/Bratislava_Castle "Bratislava Castle")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Bratislava_-_Burg_%28c%29.JPG/220px-Bratislava_-_Burg_%28c%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:Bratislava_-_Burg_(c).JPG) Bratislava Castle

One of the most prominent structures in the city is [Bratislava Castle](/wiki/Bratislava_Castle "Bratislava Castle") (*Bratislavský hrad* ), situated on a plateau 85 metres (279 ft) above the Danube. The castle hill site has been inhabited since the transitional period between the [Stone](/wiki/Stone_Age "Stone Age") and [Bronze](/wiki/Bronze_Age "Bronze Age") ages^[\[111\]](#cite_note-113)^ and has been the [acropolis](/wiki/Acropolis "Acropolis") of a [Celtic](/wiki/Celts "Celts") town, part of the [Roman](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire") [limes](/wiki/Limes_(Roman_Empire) "Limes (Roman Empire)") Romanus, a huge Slavic fortified settlement, and a political, military and religious centre for [Great Moravia](/wiki/Great_Moravia "Great Moravia").^[\[112\]](#cite_note-114)^ A stone [castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle") was not constructed until the 10th century, when the area was part of the [Kingdom of Hungary](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary "Kingdom of Hungary"), however, in the [9th century](/wiki/9th_century "9th century") a [pre-romanesque stone basilica](/wiki/Great_Moravian_Basilica_in_Bratislava "Great Moravian Basilica in Bratislava"), was standing in the area of the hillfort.{#cite_ref-114}

The castle was converted into a [Gothic](/wiki/International_Gothic "International Gothic") anti-[Hussite](/wiki/Hussite "Hussite") fortress under [Sigismund of Luxemburg](/wiki/Sigismund,_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Sigismund, Holy Roman Emperor") in 1430, became a [Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance "Renaissance") castle in 1562,^[\[113\]](#cite_note-115)^ and was rebuilt in 1649 in the [baroque](/wiki/Baroque "Baroque") style. Under [Queen](/wiki/Queen_regnant "Queen regnant") [Maria Theresa](/wiki/Maria_Theresa_of_Austria "Maria Theresa of Austria"), the castle became a prestigious royal seat. In 1811, the castle was inadvertently destroyed by fire and lay in ruins until the 1950s,^[\[114\]](#cite_note-116)^ when it was rebuilt mostly in its former Theresian style. In the 1940s, it was planned to demolish the castle ruins and replace them with a new university complex. However, it was never realised, and in the 1960s, reconstruction began. Nowadays, it serves ceremonial purposes and as a historical museum of the [Slovak National Museum](/wiki/Slovak_National_Museum "Slovak National Museum").{#cite_ref-116}  

### Devín Castle {#Dev.C3.ADn_Castle}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Devín Castle")\]  
Main article: [Devín Castle](/wiki/Dev%C3%ADn_Castle "Devín Castle")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Dev%C3%ADn_Castle_%283705531512%29.jpg/195px-Dev%C3%ADn_Castle_%283705531512%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dev%C3%ADn_Castle_(3705531512).jpg)  
Ruins of Devín Castle, first written reference to the Devin Castle dates back to 864.^[\[115\]](#cite_note-117)^  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Castle_Devin_-_walls_and_river.JPG/195px-Castle_Devin_-_walls_and_river.JPG)](/wiki/File:Castle_Devin_-_walls_and_river.JPG)  
View from Devín Castle

The ruined and recently renovated [Devín Castle](/wiki/Dev%C3%ADn_Castle "Devín Castle") is in the borough of [Devín](/wiki/Dev%C3%ADn "Devín"), on top of a rock where the [Morava River](/wiki/Morava_(river) "Morava (river)"), which forms the border between Austria and Slovakia, enters the Danube. It is one of the most important Slovak archaeological sites and contains a museum dedicated to its history.^[\[116\]](#cite_note-118)^ Due to its strategic location, Devín Castle was a very important frontier castle of [Great Moravia](/wiki/Great_Moravia "Great Moravia") and the early Hungarian state. It was destroyed by Napoleon's troops in 1809. It is an important symbol of Slovak and Slavic history.^[\[117\]](#cite_note-119)^{#cite_ref-119}  

### Rusovce {#Rusovce}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Rusovce")\]

[Rusovce mansion](/wiki/Rusovce_mansion "Rusovce mansion"), with its [English park](/wiki/English_garden "English garden"), is in the Rusovce borough. The house was originally built in the 17th century and was turned into an English [neo-Gothic](/wiki/Gothic_Revival_architecture "Gothic Revival architecture")-style mansion in 1841--1844.^[\[118\]](#cite_note-120)^ The borough is also known for the ruins of the Roman military camp [Gerulata](/wiki/Gerulata "Gerulata"), part of limes Romanus, a border defence system. Gerulata was built and used between the 1st and 4th centuries [AD](/wiki/Anno_Domini "Anno Domini").^[\[119\]](#cite_note-121)^{#cite_ref-121}  

### Parks and lakes {#Parks_and_lakes}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Parks and lakes")\]  
Further information: [Parks and gardens in Bratislava](/wiki/Parks_and_gardens_in_Bratislava "Parks and gardens in Bratislava")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/KUCHAJDA_Z_KOLOSEA_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-KUCHAJDA_Z_KOLOSEA_-_panoramio.jpg)](/wiki/File:KUCHAJDA_Z_KOLOSEA_-_panoramio.jpg) Kuchajda lake

Due to its location in the foothills of the [Little Carpathians](/wiki/Little_Carpathians "Little Carpathians") and its [riparian vegetation](/wiki/Riparian_zone "Riparian zone") on the Danubian [floodplains](/wiki/Floodplain "Floodplain"), Bratislava has forests close to the city centre. The total amount of public green space is 46.8 square kilometres (18.1 sq mi), or 110 square metres (1,200 sq ft) per inhabitant.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-122)^ The largest city park is Horský park (literally, Mountainous Park), in the Old Town. [Bratislavský lesný park](/wiki/Bratislavsk%C3%BD_lesn%C3%BD_park "Bratislavský lesný park") (Bratislava Forest Park) is located in the Little Carpathians and includes many locales popular among visitors, such as *Železná studienka* and [Koliba](/wiki/Koliba "Koliba"). The Forest Park covers an area of 27.3 square kilometres (10.5 sq mi), of which 96% is forested mostly with [oak](/wiki/Oak "Oak") and mixed oak/[hornbeam](/wiki/European_hornbeam "European hornbeam") forest, and contains original flora and fauna such as [European badgers](/wiki/European_badger "European badger"), [red foxes](/wiki/Red_fox "Red fox"), [wild boar](/wiki/Wild_boar "Wild boar") and [red](/wiki/Red_deer "Red deer") and [roe deer](/wiki/Roe_deer "Roe deer"). On the right bank of the Danube, in the borough of Petržalka, is [Janko Kráľ Park](/wiki/Sad_Janka_Kr%C3%A1%C4%BEa "Sad Janka Kráľa") founded in 1774--76.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-123)^ A new city park is planned for Petržalka between the Malý Draždiak and Veľký Draždiak lakes.^[\[110\]](#cite_note-nahalkova-112)^{#cite_ref-nahalkova_112-1}

[Bratislava's zoological park](/wiki/Bratislava_Zoo "Bratislava Zoo") is located in [Mlynská dolina](/wiki/Mlynsk%C3%A1_dolina "Mlynská dolina"), near the headquarters of [Slovak Television](/wiki/Slovensk%C3%A1_telev%C3%ADzia "Slovenská televízia"). The zoo, founded in 1960, currently houses 152 species of animals, including the rare [white lion](/wiki/White_lion "White lion") and [white tiger](/wiki/White_tiger "White tiger"). The Botanical Gardens, which belong to [Comenius University](/wiki/Comenius_University_in_Bratislava "Comenius University in Bratislava"), can be found on the Danube riverfront and house more than 120 species of domestic and foreign origin.^[\[122\]](#cite_note-124)^{#cite_ref-124}

The city has a number of natural and human-made lakes, most of which are used for recreation. Examples include Štrkovec lake in [Ružinov](/wiki/Ru%C5%BEinov "Ružinov"), Kuchajda in [Nové Mesto](/wiki/Nov%C3%A9_Mesto,_Bratislava "Nové Mesto, Bratislava"), [Zlaté Piesky](/wiki/Zlat%C3%A9_Piesky "Zlaté Piesky") and the [Vajnory](/wiki/Vajnory "Vajnory") lakes in the north-east, and [Rusovce](/wiki/Rusovce "Rusovce") lake in the south, which is popular with [nudists](/wiki/Naturism "Naturism").^[\[123\]](#cite_note-125)^{#cite_ref-125}

From the city's origin until the 19th century, Germans were the dominant ethnic group.^[\[27\]](#cite_note-Czechreview-29)^ By the end of [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"), 42% of the population of Pressburg spoke German as their native language, 40% Hungarian, and 15% Slovak.^[\[27\]](#cite_note-Czechreview-29)^

[Historical population]

After the formation of the [Czechoslovak Republic](/wiki/History_of_Czechoslovakia_(1918%E2%80%931938) "History of Czechoslovakia (1918–1938)") in 1918, Bratislava remained a multi-ethnic city, but with a different demographic trend. Due to [Slovakization](/wiki/Slovakization "Slovakization"),^[\[129\]](#cite_note-131)^^[\[130\]](#cite_note-132)^ the proportion of Slovaks and Czechs increased in the city, while the proportion of Germans and Hungarians fell. In 1938, 59% of the population were Slovaks or Czechs, while Germans represented 22% and Hungarians 13% of the city's population.^[\[131\]](#cite_note-133)^ The creation of the [first Slovak Republic](/wiki/Slovak_Republic_(1939%E2%80%931945) "Slovak Republic (1939–1945)") in 1939 brought other changes, most notably the expulsion of many Czechs and the deportation or flight of the Jews during the [Holocaust](/wiki/Holocaust "Holocaust").^[\[27\]](#cite_note-Czechreview-29)^^[\[132\]](#cite_note-134)^ In 1945, most of the Germans were evacuated. After the restoration of Czechoslovakia, the [Beneš decrees](/wiki/Bene%C5%A1_decrees "Beneš decrees") (partly revoked in 1948) collectively punished ethnic German and Hungarian minorities by expropriation and deportation to Germany, Austria, and Hungary for their alleged collaborationism with Nazi Germany and Hungary against Czechoslovakia.^[\[77\]](#cite_note-post-war-79)^^[\[133\]](#cite_note-135)^^[\[134\]](#cite_note-136)^{#cite_ref-136}

The city thereby obtained its clearly Slovak character.^[\[77\]](#cite_note-post-war-79)^ Hundreds of citizens were expelled during the communist oppression of the 1950s, with the aim of replacing "reactionary" people with the proletarian class.^[\[27\]](#cite_note-Czechreview-29)^^[\[77\]](#cite_note-post-war-79)^ Since the 1950s, the Slovaks have been the dominant ethnicity in the city, making up around 90% of the city's population.^[\[27\]](#cite_note-Czechreview-29)^{#cite_ref-Czechreview_29-5}  

Politics {#Politics}
--------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Politics")\]  
See also: [Mayor of Bratislava](/wiki/Mayor_of_Bratislava "Mayor of Bratislava"), [Boroughs and localities of Bratislava](/wiki/Boroughs_and_localities_of_Bratislava "Boroughs and localities of Bratislava"), and [International relations of Bratislava](/wiki/International_relations_of_Bratislava "International relations of Bratislava")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Grassalkovich_Palace_%282%29.jpg/220px-Grassalkovich_Palace_%282%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Grassalkovich_Palace_(2).jpg) [Grassalkovich Palace](/wiki/Grassalkovich_Palace "Grassalkovich Palace"), seat of the president of Slovakia

Bratislava is the seat of the [Slovak parliament](/wiki/National_Council_of_the_Slovak_Republic "National Council of the Slovak Republic"), [presidency](/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Slovakia "List of Presidents of Slovakia"), ministries, supreme court ([Slovak](/wiki/Slovak_language "Slovak language"): *Najvyšší súd* ), and [central bank](/wiki/National_Bank_of_Slovakia "National Bank of Slovakia"). It is the seat of the [Bratislava Region](/wiki/Bratislava_Region "Bratislava Region") and, since 2002, also of the Bratislava Self-Governing Region. The city hosts 41 foreign [embassies](/wiki/Diplomatic_mission "Diplomatic mission") and 22 [consulates](/wiki/Consul_(representative) "Consul (representative)").^[\[135\]](#cite_note-137)^{#cite_ref-137}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Bratislava%2C_Parlament%2C_Slovensko.jpg/220px-Bratislava%2C_Parlament%2C_Slovensko.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bratislava,_Parlament,_Slovensko.jpg) The building of the [National Council](/wiki/National_Council_(Slovakia) "National Council (Slovakia)") of the Slovak Republic

The current local government (*Mestská samospráva* )^[\[136\]](#cite_note-citygovt-138)^ structure has been in place since 1990.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-citygovthistory-139)^ It is composed of a [mayor](/wiki/Mayor "Mayor") (*primátor* ),^[\[138\]](#cite_note-mayor-140)^ a city board (*Mestská rada* ),^[\[139\]](#cite_note-cityboard-141)^ a [city council](/wiki/City_council "City council") (*Mestské zastupiteľstvo* ),^[\[140\]](#cite_note-citycouncil-142)^ [city commissions](/wiki/City_commission_government "City commission government") (*Komisie mestského zastupiteľstva* ),^[\[141\]](#cite_note-citycommission-143)^ and a city [magistrate](/wiki/Magistrate "Magistrate")'s office (*Magistrát* ).^[\[142\]](#cite_note-magistrate-144)^{#cite_ref-magistrate_144-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Bratislava%2C_Letn%C3%BD_arcibiskupsk%C3%BD_pal%C3%A1c%2C_Slovensko.jpg/220px-Bratislava%2C_Letn%C3%BD_arcibiskupsk%C3%BD_pal%C3%A1c%2C_Slovensko.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bratislava,_Letn%C3%BD_arcibiskupsk%C3%BD_pal%C3%A1c,_Slovensko.jpg) [Episcopal Summer Palace](/wiki/Episcopal_Summer_Palace,_Bratislava "Episcopal Summer Palace, Bratislava"), the seat of the [government of Slovakia](/wiki/Government_of_Slovakia "Government of Slovakia")

The mayor, based at the [Primate's Palace](/wiki/Primate%27s_Palace,_Bratislava "Primate's Palace, Bratislava"), is the city's top executive officer and is elected to a four-year term of office. The current mayor of Bratislava is [Matúš Vallo](/wiki/Mat%C3%BA%C5%A1_Vallo "Matúš Vallo"), who won the [election](/wiki/2022_Slovak_local_elections "2022 Slovak local elections") held on October 29, 2022, as an independent candidate. The city council is the city's legislative body, responsible for issues such as budget, local ordinances, [city planning](/wiki/Urban_planning "Urban planning"), road maintenance, education, and culture.^[\[143\]](#cite_note-145)^{#cite_ref-145}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/%D0%90%D1%80%D1%85%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%BF%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BF%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%B4%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%86_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-%D0%90%D1%80%D1%85%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%BF%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BF%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%B4%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%86_-_panoramio.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%90%D1%80%D1%85%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%BF%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BF%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%B4%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%86_-_panoramio.jpg) [Primate's Palace](/wiki/Primate%27s_Palace,_Bratislava "Primate's Palace, Bratislava") at [Primate's Square](/wiki/Primate%27s_Square "Primate's Square"), the seat of the city's mayor  

### City Council {#City_Council}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: City Council")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Bratislava_Magistrat.JPG/220px-Bratislava_Magistrat.JPG)](/wiki/File:Bratislava_Magistrat.JPG) The building of the City Council

The Bratislava City Council is the legislature of the City of Bratislava. It has 45 members. The Council usually convenes once a month and consists of 45 members elected to four-year terms concurrent with the mayor's. Many of the council's executive functions are carried out by the city commission at the council's direction.^[\[141\]](#cite_note-citycommission-143)^ The city board is a 28-member body composed of the mayor and his deputies, the borough mayors, and up to ten city council members. The board is an executive and supervisory arm of the city council and also serves in an advisory role to the mayor.^[\[139\]](#cite_note-cityboard-141)^{#cite_ref-cityboard_141-1}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Bratislava%2C_Hlavn%C3%A9_n%C3%A1mestie%2C_Slovensko.jpg/220px-Bratislava%2C_Hlavn%C3%A9_n%C3%A1mestie%2C_Slovensko.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bratislava,_Hlavn%C3%A9_n%C3%A1mestie,_Slovensko.jpg) Embassy of Japan (left) and Greece (right) at the [Main Square](/wiki/Hlavn%C3%A9_n%C3%A1mestie_(Bratislava) "Hlavné námestie (Bratislava)"). There are 41 embassies and 22 honorary consulates in Bratislava.  

### Administration {#Administration}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Administration")\]

Administratively, Bratislava is divided into five [districts](/wiki/Districts_of_Slovakia "Districts of Slovakia"): Bratislava I (the city centre), Bratislava II (eastern parts), Bratislava III (north-eastern parts), Bratislava IV (western and northern parts) and Bratislava V (southern parts on the right bank of the Danube, including Petržalka, the most densely populated residential area in [Central Europe](/wiki/Central_Europe "Central Europe")).^[\[144\]](#cite_note-petrzalkacity-146)^{#cite_ref-petrzalkacity_146-0}

For self-governance purposes, the city is divided into 17 boroughs, each of which has its own mayor (*starosta* ) and council. The number of councillors in each depends on the size and population of the borough.^[\[145\]](#cite_note-localgovernment-147)^ Each of the boroughs coincides with the city's 20 [cadastral areas](/wiki/Cadastre "Cadastre"), except for two cases: Nové Mesto is further divided into the Nové Mesto and Vinohrady cadastral areas and Ružinov is divided into Ružinov, Nivy and Trnávka. Further unofficial division recognizes additional quarters and localities.{#cite_ref-localgovernment_147-0}

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Economy")\]  
Main article: [Economy of Bratislava](/wiki/Economy_of_Bratislava "Economy of Bratislava")  
See also: [List of tallest buildings in Bratislava](/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_Bratislava "List of tallest buildings in Bratislava")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Nbs.jpg/170px-Nbs.jpg)](/wiki/File:Nbs.jpg) [National Bank of Slovakia](/wiki/National_Bank_of_Slovakia "National Bank of Slovakia")

The [Bratislava Region](/wiki/Bratislava_Region "Bratislava Region") is the wealthiest and most economically prosperous region in Slovakia, despite being the smallest by area and having the third smallest population of [the eight Slovak regions](/wiki/Regions_of_Slovakia "Regions of Slovakia"). It accounts for about 26% of the Slovak [GDP](/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product").^[\[146\]](#cite_note-148)^ According to [GDP](/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product") per capita, Bratislava is the 19th-richest region in the European Union in 2023.^[\[147\]](#cite_note-:0-149)^ The unemployment rate in Bratislava was 2,38% in June 2023.^[\[148\]](#cite_note-150)^ The average monthly salary in the Bratislava region in 2024 was €2,150.^[\[149\]](#cite_note-151)^{#cite_ref-151}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Bratislava_z_Dunaja_3.jpg/170px-Bratislava_z_Dunaja_3.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bratislava_z_Dunaja_3.jpg) Residential building [Eurovea Tower](/wiki/Eurovea_Tower "Eurovea Tower"), the tallest building in Slovakia

Many governmental institutions and private companies have their headquarters in Bratislava. More than 75% of Bratislava's population works in the [service sector](/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy "Tertiary sector of the economy"), mainly composed of [trade](/wiki/Trade "Trade"), [banking](/wiki/Bank "Bank"), [IT](/wiki/Information_technology "Information technology"), [telecommunications](/wiki/Telecommunication "Telecommunication"), and [tourism](/wiki/Tourism "Tourism").^[\[150\]](#cite_note-152)^ The [Bratislava Stock Exchange](/wiki/Bratislava_Stock_Exchange "Bratislava Stock Exchange") (BSSE), the organiser of the public securities market, was founded on 15 March 1991.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-153)^{#cite_ref-153}

Companies operating predominantly in Bratislava with the highest value added according to the 2018 *[Trend](https://sk.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trend_(slovensk%C3%A9_periodikum) "sk:Trend (slovenské periodikum)")* Top 200 ranking, include the [Volkswagen Bratislava Plant](/wiki/Volkswagen_Bratislava_Plant "Volkswagen Bratislava Plant"), Slovnaft refinery (MOL), [Eset](/wiki/Eset "Eset") (software developer), Asseco (software company), PPC Power (producer of heat and steam) and Trenkwalder personnel agency.^[\[152\]](#cite_note-154)^{#cite_ref-154}

[Volkswagen Group](/wiki/Volkswagen_Group "Volkswagen Group") took over and expanded the [BAZ](https://sk.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bratislavsk%C3%A9_automobilov%C3%A9_z%C3%A1vody "sk:Bratislavské automobilové závody") factory in 1991, and has since considerably expanded production beyond original [Skoda Auto](/wiki/Skoda_Auto "Skoda Auto") models.^[\[153\]](#cite_note-155)^ Currently,^\[*[timeframe?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Relative_time_references "Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch")*\]^ 68% of production is focused on [SUVs](/wiki/Sport_utility_vehicle "Sport utility vehicle"): [Audi Q7](/wiki/Audi_Q7 "Audi Q7"); [VW Touareg](/wiki/Volkswagen_Touareg "Volkswagen Touareg"); as well as the body and under-chassis of the [Porsche Cayenne](/wiki/Porsche_Cayenne "Porsche Cayenne"). Since 2012, production has also included the [Volkswagen up!](/wiki/Volkswagen_up! "Volkswagen up!"), [SEAT Mii](/wiki/SEAT_Mii "SEAT Mii") and [Skoda Citigo](/wiki/Skoda_Citigo "Skoda Citigo").^[\[154\]](#cite_note-156)^{#cite_ref-156}

In recent years, [service](/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy "Tertiary sector of the economy") and [high-tech](/wiki/High_tech "High tech")-oriented businesses have prospered in Bratislava. Many global companies, including [IBM](/wiki/IBM "IBM"), [Dell](/wiki/Dell "Dell"), [Lenovo](/wiki/Lenovo "Lenovo"), [AT\&T](/wiki/AT%26T "AT&T"), [SAP](/wiki/SAP_AG "SAP AG"), [Amazon](/wiki/Amazon_(company) "Amazon (company)"), [Johnson Controls](/wiki/Johnson_Controls "Johnson Controls"), [Swiss Re](/wiki/Swiss_Re "Swiss Re") and [Accenture](/wiki/Accenture "Accenture"), have built [outsourcing](/wiki/Outsourcing "Outsourcing") and service centres here.^[\[155\]](#cite_note-157)^ Reasons for the influx of [multi-national corporations](/wiki/Multinational_corporation "Multinational corporation") include proximity to Western Europe, skilled labour force and the high density of universities and research facilities.^[\[156\]](#cite_note-158)^ Also Slovak IT companies including [ESET](/wiki/ESET "ESET"), [Sygic](/wiki/Sygic "Sygic") and [Pixel Federation](/wiki/Pixel_Federation "Pixel Federation") have headquarters in Bratislava.{#cite_ref-158}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Slovakia_bratislava_Star%C3%BD_most_2.jpg/250px-Slovakia_bratislava_Star%C3%BD_most_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Slovakia_bratislava_Star%C3%BD_most_2.jpg) High-rise buildings in new Bratislava downtown. The area is composed of [Sky Park](/wiki/Sky_Park_(Bratislava) "Sky Park (Bratislava)"), [Eurovea City](/wiki/Eurovea_City "Eurovea City") and New Nivy, 2024

Other large companies and employers with headquarters in Bratislava include [Slovak Telekom](/wiki/Slovak_Telekom "Slovak Telekom"), [Orange Slovensko](/wiki/Orange_Slovensko "Orange Slovensko"), [Slovenská sporiteľňa](/wiki/Slovensk%C3%A1_sporite%C4%BE%C5%88a "Slovenská sporiteľňa"), [Tatra banka](/wiki/Tatra_banka "Tatra banka"), [Doprastav](/wiki/Doprastav "Doprastav"), [Hewlett-Packard](/wiki/Hewlett-Packard "Hewlett-Packard") Slovakia, [Slovnaft](/wiki/Slovnaft "Slovnaft"), [Henkel](/wiki/Henkel "Henkel") Slovensko,^[\[157\]](#cite_note-159)^ [Slovenský plynárenský priemysel](/wiki/Slovensk%C3%BD_plyn%C3%A1rensk%C3%BD_priemysel "Slovenský plynárenský priemysel"), [Kraft Foods](/wiki/Kraft_Foods "Kraft Foods") Slovakia, [Whirlpool Slovakia](/wiki/Whirlpool_Corporation "Whirlpool Corporation"), [Železnice Slovenskej republiky](/wiki/Railways_of_Slovak_Republic_%E2%80%93_%C5%BDSR "Railways of Slovak Republic – ŽSR"), [AeroMobil](/wiki/AeroMobil_s.r.o._AeroMobil "AeroMobil s.r.o. AeroMobil"), and [Tesco](/wiki/Tesco "Tesco") Stores Slovak Republic.{#cite_ref-159}

The [Slovak economy](/wiki/Economy_of_Slovakia "Economy of Slovakia")'s strong growth in the 2000s has led to a boom in the construction industry, and several major projects have been completed or are planned in Bratislava.^[\[108\]](#cite_note-realestate-110)^ Areas attracting developers include the [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube") riverfront, where two major projects are already finished: River Park in the Old Town, and [Eurovea](/wiki/Eurovea "Eurovea") near the Apollo Bridge.^[\[158\]](#cite_note-160)^^[\[159\]](#cite_note-161)^ Other locations under development include the areas around the main railway and bus stations, the former industrial zone near the Old Town and in the boroughs of Petržalka, Nové Mesto and Ružinov.^[\[144\]](#cite_note-petrzalkacity-146)^^[\[160\]](#cite_note-162)^^[\[161\]](#cite_note-163)^ In 2010, the city had a balanced budget of €277 million, with one fifth used for investment.^[\[162\]](#cite_note-budget-164)^ Bratislava holds shares in 17 companies directly, including the city's public transport company [Dopravný podnik Bratislava](/wiki/Dopravn%C3%BD_podnik_Bratislava "Dopravný podnik Bratislava"), the [waste collection and disposal](/wiki/Waste_collection "Waste collection") company named OLO (*Odvoz a likvidácia odpadu* ), and the water utility.^[\[163\]](#cite_note-citycompanies-165)^ The city also manages municipal organisations such as the city police (*Mestská polícia* ), [Bratislava City Museum](/wiki/Bratislava_City_Museum "Bratislava City Museum") and [ZOO Bratislava](/wiki/Bratislava_Zoo "Bratislava Zoo").^[\[164\]](#cite_note-cityorgs-166)^{#cite_ref-cityorgs_166-0}  

### Tourism {#Tourism}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Tourism")\]  
See also: [Tourism in Slovakia](/wiki/Tourism_in_Slovakia "Tourism in Slovakia")

In 2022 a total of 927,950 people came to visit Bratislava and spent there 1,719,409 nights.^[\[165\]](#cite_note-:2-167)^ These were most commonly 65% foreigners. Bratislava attracts predominantly visitors from the neighboring and nearby countries - Czech Republic, Germany, Austria and Poland. The top 5 is closed by visitors from the UK. Bratislava offered 272 accommodation facilities with 10,338 rooms in 2022.^[\[165\]](#cite_note-:2-167)^ A considerable share of visits is made by those who visit Bratislava for a single day, but their exact number is not available.{#cite_ref-:2_167-1}

Among other factors, the growth of [low-cost airline](/wiki/Low-cost_carrier "Low-cost carrier") flights to Bratislava, led by [Ryanair](/wiki/Ryanair "Ryanair"), has led to conspicuous [stag parties](/wiki/Bachelor_party "Bachelor party"), primarily from the UK. While these are a boom to the city's tourism industry, cultural differences and [vandalism](/wiki/Vandalism "Vandalism") have led to concern by local officials.^[\[166\]](#cite_note-stagparty-168)^ Reflecting the popularity of rowdy parties in Bratislava in the early to mid-2000s, the city was a setting in the 2004 comedy film *[Eurotrip](/wiki/EuroTrip "EuroTrip")* , which was actually filmed in the city of [Prague](/wiki/Prague "Prague"), the Czech Republic.{#cite_ref-stagparty_168-0}

### Shopping {#Shopping}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Shopping")\]

Bratislava has eight major shopping centres: [Aupark](/wiki/Aupark "Aupark"), [Avion Shopping Park](/wiki/Avion_Shopping_Park "Avion Shopping Park"), Bory Mall, [Central](/wiki/Central_(shopping_mall) "Central (shopping mall)"), [Eurovea Galleria](/wiki/Eurovea_Galleria "Eurovea Galleria"), [Nivy](/wiki/Nivy "Nivy") Centrum, [Vivo!](/wiki/Polus_City_Center "Polus City Center") (formerly Polus City Center) and Shopping Palace.

A month before Christmas, the [Main Square](/wiki/Hlavn%C3%A9_n%C3%A1mestie_(Bratislava) "Hlavné námestie (Bratislava)") in Bratislava is illuminated by a Christmas tree and the Christmas market stalls are officially opened. Around 100 booths are opened every year. It is opened most of the day as well as in the evening.
