Culture {#Culture}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Culture")\]

Bratislava is the cultural heart of Slovakia. Owing to its historical multi-cultural character, local culture is influenced by various ethnic and religious groups, including Germans, Slovaks, Hungarians, and Jews.^[\[167\]](#cite_note-169)^ Bratislava enjoys numerous theatres, museums, galleries, concert halls, cinemas, film clubs, and foreign cultural institutions.^[\[168\]](#cite_note-170)^{#cite_ref-170}  

### Performing arts {#Performing_arts}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Performing arts")\]

Bratislava is the seat of the [Slovak National Theatre](/wiki/Slovak_National_Theatre "Slovak National Theatre"), housed in two buildings.^[\[169\]](#cite_note-Slovak_National_Theatre-171)^ The first is a [Neo-Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance_Revival_architecture "Renaissance Revival architecture") theatre building situated in the Old Town at the end of [Hviezdoslav Square](/wiki/Hviezdoslavovo_n%C3%A1mestie_(Bratislava) "Hviezdoslavovo námestie (Bratislava)"). The new building, opened to the public in 2007, is on the riverfront.^[\[109\]](#cite_note-liptakova-111)^^[\[169\]](#cite_note-Slovak_National_Theatre-171)^ The theatre has three ensembles: opera, ballet and drama.^[\[169\]](#cite_note-Slovak_National_Theatre-171)^ Smaller theatres include the [New Scene Theatre](/wiki/New_Scene "New Scene"), the [Astorka Korzo '90 Theatre](/wiki/Astorka_Korzo_%2790_Theatre "Astorka Korzo '90 Theatre"), the [Arena Theatre](/wiki/Arena_Theatre "Arena Theatre"), the L+S Studio, the Naive Theatre of Radošina and the Bratislava Puppet Theatre.{#cite_ref-Slovak_National_Theatre_171-2}

Music in Bratislava flourished in the 18th century and was closely linked to Viennese musical life. [Mozart](/wiki/Wolfgang_Amadeus_Mozart "Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart") visited the town at the age of six. Among other notable composers who visited or lived in the town were [Haydn](/wiki/Joseph_Haydn "Joseph Haydn"), [Liszt](/wiki/Franz_Liszt "Franz Liszt"),^[\[170\]](#cite_note-172)^ [Bartók](/wiki/B%C3%A9la_Bart%C3%B3k "Béla Bartók") and [Beethoven](/wiki/Ludwig_van_Beethoven "Ludwig van Beethoven"). It is also the birthplace of the composers [Johann Nepomuk Hummel](/wiki/Johann_Nepomuk_Hummel "Johann Nepomuk Hummel"), [Ernő Dohnányi](/wiki/Ern%C5%91_Dohn%C3%A1nyi "Ernő Dohnányi"), and [Franz Schmidt](/wiki/Franz_Schmidt_(composer) "Franz Schmidt (composer)"). Bratislava is home to both the [Slovak Philharmonic](/wiki/Slovak_Philharmonic "Slovak Philharmonic") Orchestra and the [chamber orchestra](/wiki/Chamber_orchestra "Chamber orchestra"), [Capella Istropolitana](/wiki/Capella_Istropolitana "Capella Istropolitana"). The city hosts several annual festivals, such as the [Bratislava Music Festival](/wiki/Bratislava_Music_Festival "Bratislava Music Festival") and [Bratislava Jazz Days](/wiki/Bratislava_Jazz_Days "Bratislava Jazz Days").^[\[171\]](#cite_note-173)^ During the summer, various musical events take place as part of the Bratislava Cultural Summer at [Bratislava Castle](/wiki/Bratislava_Castle "Bratislava Castle"). Apart from musical festivals, it is possible to hear music ranging from underground to well known pop stars.^[\[172\]](#cite_note-travelmusic-174)^{#cite_ref-travelmusic_174-0}

Bratislava is home to two of Slovakia's national folk dance ensembles, Lúčnica and Slovenský ľudový umelecký kolektív (SĽUK).^[\[173\]](#cite_note-175)^^[\[174\]](#cite_note-176)^^[\[175\]](#cite_note-177)^{#cite_ref-177}

### Museums and galleries {#Museums_and_galleries}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Museums and galleries")\]  
Main article: [Museums and galleries of Bratislava](/wiki/Museums_and_galleries_of_Bratislava "Museums and galleries of Bratislava")

The [Slovak National Museum](/wiki/Slovak_National_Museum "Slovak National Museum") (*Slovenské národné múzeum* ), founded in 1961, has its headquarters in Bratislava on the riverfront in the Old Town, along with the Natural History Museum, which is one of its subdivisions. It is the largest cultural [institution](/wiki/Institution "Institution") in Slovakia, and manages 16 specialized museums in Bratislava and beyond.^[\[176\]](#cite_note-178)^ The [Bratislava City Museum](/wiki/Bratislava_City_Museum "Bratislava City Museum") (*Múzeum mesta Bratislavy* ), established in 1868, is the oldest museum in continuous operation in Slovakia.^[\[177\]](#cite_note-179)^ Its primary goal is to chronicle Bratislava's history in various forms from the earliest periods using historical and archaeological collections. It offers permanent displays in eight specialised museums.{#cite_ref-179}

The [Slovak National Gallery](/wiki/Slovak_National_Gallery "Slovak National Gallery"), founded in 1948, offers the most extensive network of galleries in Slovakia. Two displays in Bratislava are next to one another at [Esterházy Palace](/wiki/Esterh%C3%A1zy_Palace_(Bratislava) "Esterházy Palace (Bratislava)") (*Esterházyho palác* ) and the Water Barracks (*Vodné kasárne* ) on the Danube riverfront in the Old Town. The [Bratislava City Gallery](/wiki/Bratislava_City_Gallery "Bratislava City Gallery"), founded in 1961, is the second-largest Slovak gallery of its kind. The gallery offers permanent displays at [Pálffy Palace](/wiki/Johann_P%C3%A1lffy_Palace "Johann Pálffy Palace") (*Pálffyho palác* ) and [Mirbach Palace](/wiki/Mirbach_Palace "Mirbach Palace") (*Mirbachov palác* ), in the Old Town.^[\[178\]](#cite_note-Citygallery-180)^ Danubiana Art Museum, one of the youngest art museums in Europe, is near [Čunovo](/wiki/%C4%8Cunovo "Čunovo") [waterworks](/wiki/Gab%C4%8D%C3%ADkovo_%E2%80%93_Nagymaros_Dams "Gabčíkovo – Nagymaros Dams").^[\[179\]](#cite_note-181)^{#cite_ref-181}

### Media {#Media}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Media")\]  
See also: [Television in Slovakia](/wiki/Television_in_Slovakia "Television in Slovakia"), [List of radio stations in Slovakia](/wiki/List_of_radio_stations_in_Slovakia "List of radio stations in Slovakia"), and [List of newspapers in Slovakia](/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_Slovakia "List of newspapers in Slovakia")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Upside_down_Pyramid%2C_Bratislava_02.jpg/220px-Upside_down_Pyramid%2C_Bratislava_02.jpg)](/wiki/File:Upside_down_Pyramid,_Bratislava_02.jpg) [Slovak Radio Building](/wiki/Slovak_Radio_Building "Slovak Radio Building")

As the national capital, Bratislava is home to national and many local media outlets. Notable TV stations based in the city include [Slovak Television and Radio](/wiki/Slovak_Television_and_Radio "Slovak Television and Radio") (*Slovenská televízia a rozhlas* ), [Markíza](/wiki/Mark%C3%ADza "Markíza"), [JOJ](/wiki/TV_JOJ "TV JOJ") and [TA3](/wiki/TA3_(news_channel) "TA3 (news channel)"). [STVR](/wiki/Slovak_Television_and_Radio "Slovak Television and Radio") radio's [headquarters](/wiki/Slovak_Radio_Building "Slovak Radio Building") has its seat in the centre, and many Slovak commercial radio stations are based in the city. National newspapers based in Bratislava include *[SME](/wiki/SME_(newspaper) "SME (newspaper)")* , *[Pravda](/wiki/Pravda_(Slovakia) "Pravda (Slovakia)")* , *[Nový čas](/wiki/Nov%C3%BD_%C4%8Das "Nový čas")* , *[Hospodárske noviny](/wiki/Hospod%C3%A1rske_noviny "Hospodárske noviny")* and the English-language *[The Slovak Spectator](/wiki/The_Slovak_Spectator "The Slovak Spectator")* . Two news agencies are headquartered there: the [News Agency of the Slovak Republic](/wiki/News_Agency_of_the_Slovak_Republic "News Agency of the Slovak Republic") (*TASR, Tlačová agentúra Slovenskej republiky* ) and the Slovak News Agency (*SITA, Slovenská tlačová agentúra*).  

Sport {#Sport}
--------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Sport")\]  
Main article: [Sport in Bratislava](/wiki/Sport_in_Bratislava "Sport in Bratislava")

Various [sports](/wiki/Sport "Sport") and sports teams have a long tradition in Bratislava, with many teams and individuals competing in Slovak and international [leagues](/wiki/Sports_league "Sports league") and [competitions](/wiki/Competition "Competition").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Slovakia_bratislava_N%C3%A1rodn%C3%BD_futbalov%C3%BD_%C5%A1tadi%C3%B3n.jpg/220px-Slovakia_bratislava_N%C3%A1rodn%C3%BD_futbalov%C3%BD_%C5%A1tadi%C3%B3n.jpg)](/wiki/File:Slovakia_bratislava_N%C3%A1rodn%C3%BD_futbalov%C3%BD_%C5%A1tadi%C3%B3n.jpg) [National football stadium](/wiki/Teheln%C3%A9_pole "Tehelné pole")

[Football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") is currently represented by the only club playing in the top Slovak football league, the [Fortuna Liga](/wiki/Slovak_Superliga "Slovak Superliga"). [ŠK Slovan Bratislava](/wiki/%C5%A0K_Slovan_Bratislava "ŠK Slovan Bratislava"), founded in 1919, has its home ground at the [Tehelné pole](/wiki/Teheln%C3%A9_pole "Tehelné pole") stadium. ŠK Slovan is the most successful football club in Slovak history, being the only club from the former [Czechoslovakia](/wiki/Czechoslovakia "Czechoslovakia") to win the European football competition the [Cup Winners' Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Cup_Winners%27_Cup "UEFA Cup Winners' Cup"), in 1969.^[\[180\]](#cite_note-182)^ [FC Petržalka akadémia](/wiki/FC_Petr%C5%BEalka_akad%C3%A9mia "FC Petržalka akadémia") is the oldest of Bratislava's football clubs, founded in 1898, and is based at [Stadium FC Petržalka 1898](/wiki/Stadium_FC_Petr%C5%BEalka_1898 "Stadium FC Petržalka 1898") in Petržalka (formerly at [Pasienky](/wiki/Pasienky "Pasienky") in Nové Mesto and [Štadión Petržalka](/wiki/%C5%A0tadi%C3%B3n_Petr%C5%BEalka "Štadión Petržalka") in Petržalka). They are currently the only Slovak team to win at least one match in the [UEFA Champions League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions League") group stage, with a 5--0 win over [Celtic FC](/wiki/Celtic_FC "Celtic FC") in the qualifying round being the most well-known, alongside a 3--2 win over [FC Porto](/wiki/FC_Porto "FC Porto"). Before then [FC Košice](/wiki/FC_Ko%C5%A1ice "FC Košice") in the 1997--98 season lost all six matches, despite being the first Slovak side since independence to play in the competition.^[\[181\]](#cite_note-183)^{#cite_ref-183}

In 2010 Artmedia were relegated from the Corgon Liga under their new name of MFK Petržalka, finishing 12th and bottom. FC Petržalka akadémia currently competes in [5. liga](/wiki/Slovak_Fifth_Football_League "Slovak Fifth Football League") after bankruptcy in summer 2014. Another known club from the city is [FK Inter Bratislava](/wiki/FK_Inter_Bratislava "FK Inter Bratislava"). Founded in 1945, they have their home ground at [Stadium ŠKP Inter Dúbravka](/wiki/Stadium_%C5%A0KP_Inter_D%C3%BAbravka "Stadium ŠKP Inter Dúbravka") in [Dúbravka](/wiki/D%C3%BAbravka,_Bratislava "Dúbravka, Bratislava"), (formerly at Štadión Pasienky) and currently plays in the [3. liga](/wiki/3._Liga_(Slovakia) "3. Liga (Slovakia)"). There are many more clubs with long tradition and successful history despite the lack of success in last years, e.g. [LP Domino](/wiki/LP_Domino "LP Domino") Bratislava currently playing in [4. liga](/wiki/Slovak_Fourth_Football_League "Slovak Fourth Football League"); [FK Rača](/wiki/FK_Ra%C4%8Da "FK Rača") Bratislava competing in the [3. liga](/wiki/3._Liga_(Slovakia) "3. Liga (Slovakia)") as well as Inter; [FK ŠKP Inter Dúbravka Bratislava](/wiki/FK_%C5%A0KP_Inter_D%C3%BAbravka_Bratislava "FK ŠKP Inter Dúbravka Bratislava"), following ŠKP Devín (successful team from the 1990s) and partially following the original Inter (original Inter bankrupted in 2009, sold the [Corgoň Liga](/wiki/Slovak_Super_Liga "Slovak Super Liga") license to [FK Senica](/wiki/FK_Senica "FK Senica") and legally merged with FC ŠKP Dúbravka; current Inter has taken over the tradition, name, colours, fans, etc., but legally is no successor of the original Inter); [FC Tatran Devín](/w/index.php?title=FC_Tatran_Dev%C3%ADn&action=edit&redlink=1 "FC Tatran Devín (page does not exist)"), the club that was successful mostly at youth level and merged with ŠKP Bratislava in 1995; [MŠK Iskra Petržalka](/wiki/M%C5%A0K_Iskra_Petr%C5%BEalka "MŠK Iskra Petržalka"), playing under the name *ŠK Iskra Matadorfix Bratislava* in the former 1st League (today [2nd](/wiki/2._Liga_(Slovakia) "2. Liga (Slovakia)")) in [1997/98](/wiki/1997%E2%80%9398_Slovak_First_League "1997–98 Slovak First League").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Ondrej_nepela_arena_2019_2.jpg/220px-Ondrej_nepela_arena_2019_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ondrej_nepela_arena_2019_2.jpg) [Ondrej Nepela Arena](/wiki/Ondrej_Nepela_Arena "Ondrej Nepela Arena"), ice-hockey and mixed use arena

Bratislava is home to three winter sports arenas: [Ondrej Nepela](/wiki/Ondrej_Nepela "Ondrej Nepela") Winter Sports Stadium, [V. Dzurilla](/wiki/Vladim%C3%ADr_Dzurilla "Vladimír Dzurilla") Winter Sports Stadium, and [Dúbravka](/wiki/D%C3%BAbravka,_Bratislava "Dúbravka, Bratislava") Winter Sports Stadium. The [HC Slovan Bratislava](/wiki/HC_Slovan_Bratislava "HC Slovan Bratislava") ice hockey team has represented Bratislava from the [2012--13 season](/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_KHL_season "2012–13 KHL season") in the [Kontinental Hockey League](/wiki/Kontinental_Hockey_League "Kontinental Hockey League"). [Slovnaft Arena](/wiki/Slovnaft_Arena "Slovnaft Arena"), a part of [Ondrej Nepela](/wiki/Ondrej_Nepela "Ondrej Nepela") Winter Sports Stadium, is home to HC Slovan. The [Ice Hockey World Championships](/wiki/Ice_Hockey_World_Championships "Ice Hockey World Championships") in 1959 and 1992 were played in Bratislava, and the [2011 World Championship](/wiki/2011_IIHF_World_Championship "2011 IIHF World Championship") were held in Bratislava and [Košice](/wiki/Ko%C5%A1ice "Košice"), for which a new arena was built.^[\[182\]](#cite_note-184)^ The city also played host to the World Championship in 2019.{#cite_ref-184}

The [Čunovo Water Sports Centre](/wiki/%C4%8Cunovo_Water_Sports_Centre "Čunovo Water Sports Centre") is a [whitewater slalom](/wiki/Whitewater_slalom "Whitewater slalom") and [rafting](/wiki/Rafting "Rafting") area, close to the [Gabčíkovo dam](/wiki/Gab%C4%8D%C3%ADkovo_%E2%80%93_Nagymaros_Dams "Gabčíkovo – Nagymaros Dams"). It hosts several international and national [canoe](/wiki/Canoe "Canoe") and [kayak](/wiki/Kayak "Kayak") competitions annually.

In 1966, Bratislava named its new multi-sports stadium after tennis player [Ladislav Hecht](/wiki/Ladislav_Hecht "Ladislav Hecht").^[\[183\]](#cite_note-185)^^[\[184\]](#cite_note-186)^{#cite_ref-186}

The National Tennis Centre, which includes [Aegon Arena](/wiki/Aegon_Arena "Aegon Arena"), hosts various cultural, sporting and social events. Several [Davis Cup](/wiki/Davis_Cup "Davis Cup") matches have been played there, including the [2005 Davis Cup](/wiki/2005_Davis_Cup "2005 Davis Cup") final. The city is represented in the top Slovak leagues in women's and men's [basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball"), women's [handball](/wiki/Team_handball "Team handball") and [volleyball](/wiki/Volleyball "Volleyball"), and men's [water polo](/wiki/Water_polo "Water polo"). The Devín--Bratislava National run is the oldest athletic event in Slovakia,^[\[185\]](#cite_note-187)^ and the Bratislava City Marathon has been held annually since 2006. A [race track](/wiki/Race_track "Race track") is located in [Petržalka](/wiki/Petr%C5%BEalka "Petržalka"), where [horse racing](/wiki/Horse_racing "Horse racing") and [dog racing](/wiki/Greyhound_racing "Greyhound racing") events and [dog shows](/wiki/Dog_agility "Dog agility") are held regularly.{#cite_ref-187}

Bratislava is also the centre of [rugby union in Slovakia](/wiki/Rugby_union_in_Slovakia "Rugby union in Slovakia") and [motorcycle speedway](/wiki/Motorcycle_speedway "Motorcycle speedway") previously existed at several venues throughout the city.^[\[186\]](#cite_note-188)^{#cite_ref-188}  

Education and science {#Education_and_science}
----------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Education and science")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Blava_2007-3-28-33.jpg/195px-Blava_2007-3-28-33.jpg)](/wiki/File:Blava_2007-3-28-33.jpg)  
Universitas Istropolitana building  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Univerzita_Komensk%C3%A9ho.jpg/195px-Univerzita_Komensk%C3%A9ho.jpg)](/wiki/File:Univerzita_Komensk%C3%A9ho.jpg)  
Comenius University headquarters at Šafárikovo námestie

The first university in Bratislava, in the [Kingdom of Hungary](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary "Kingdom of Hungary") (and also in the territory of present-day Slovakia) was [Universitas Istropolitana](/wiki/Universitas_Istropolitana "Universitas Istropolitana"), founded in 1465 by King [Matthias Corvinus](/wiki/Matthias_Corvinus_of_Hungary "Matthias Corvinus of Hungary"). It was closed in 1490 after his death.^[\[187\]](#cite_note-189)^{#cite_ref-189}

Bratislava is the seat of the largest university ([Comenius University](/wiki/Comenius_University_in_Bratislava "Comenius University in Bratislava"), 27,771 students),^[\[188\]](#cite_note-uips1-190)^ the largest technical university ([Slovak University of Technology](/wiki/Slovak_University_of_Technology_in_Bratislava "Slovak University of Technology in Bratislava"), 18,473 students),^[\[189\]](#cite_note-uips21-191)^ and the oldest art schools (the [Academy of Performing Arts](/wiki/Academy_of_Performing_Arts_in_Bratislava "Academy of Performing Arts in Bratislava") and the [Academy of Fine Arts and Design](/wiki/Academy_of_Fine_Arts_and_Design_in_Bratislava "Academy of Fine Arts and Design in Bratislava")) in Slovakia. Other institutions of tertiary education are the public [University of Economics](/wiki/University_of_Economics_in_Bratislava "University of Economics in Bratislava") and the first private college in Slovakia, [City University of Seattle](/wiki/City_University_of_Seattle_(Vysok%C3%A1_%C5%A0kola_Mana%C5%BEmentu) "City University of Seattle (Vysoká Škola Manažmentu)").^[\[190\]](#cite_note-192)^ In total, about 56,000 students attend university in Bratislava.^[\[191\]](#cite_note-factsandfigures-193)^{#cite_ref-factsandfigures_193-0}

There are 65 public [primary schools](/wiki/Primary_school "Primary school"), nine private primary schools and ten religious primary schools.^[\[192\]](#cite_note-uips-194)^ Overall, they enroll 25,821 pupils.^[\[192\]](#cite_note-uips-194)^ The city's system of [secondary education](/wiki/Secondary_education "Secondary education") (some middle schools and all high schools) consists of 39 [gymnasia](/wiki/Gymnasium_(school) "Gymnasium (school)") with 16,048 students,^[\[193\]](#cite_note-uips2-195)^ 37 specialized [high schools](/wiki/High_school "High school") with 10,373 students,^[\[194\]](#cite_note-uips3-196)^ and 27 [vocational schools](/wiki/Vocational_school "Vocational school") with 8,863 students (data as of 2007^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit)^).^[\[195\]](#cite_note-uips4-197)^^[\[196\]](#cite_note-uips5-198)^{#cite_ref-uips5_198-0}

The [Slovak Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Slovak_Academy_of_Sciences "Slovak Academy of Sciences") is also based in Bratislava. However, the city is one of the few European capitals to have neither an [observatory](/wiki/Observatory "Observatory") nor a [planetarium](/wiki/Planetarium "Planetarium"). The nearest observatory is in [Modra](/wiki/Modra "Modra"), 30 kilometres (19 mi) away, and the nearest planetarium is in [Hlohovec](/wiki/Hlohovec "Hlohovec"), 70 kilometres (43 mi) away.  

Transport {#Transport}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Transport")\]  
Main articles: [Transport in Bratislava](/wiki/Transport_in_Bratislava "Transport in Bratislava") and [Public Transport in Bratislava](/wiki/Public_Transport_in_Bratislava "Public Transport in Bratislava")  
See also: [List of bridges in Bratislava city](/wiki/List_of_bridges_in_Bratislava_city "List of bridges in Bratislava city")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Bratislava_m%C3%A1_stanicu%2C_ktor%C3%A1_sa_vyrovn%C3%A1_eur%C3%B3pskym_metropol%C3%A1m._Nazrite_do_Nivy_centra_%2851536059094%29.jpg/195px-Bratislava_m%C3%A1_stanicu%2C_ktor%C3%A1_sa_vyrovn%C3%A1_eur%C3%B3pskym_metropol%C3%A1m._Nazrite_do_Nivy_centra_%2851536059094%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bratislava_m%C3%A1_stanicu,_ktor%C3%A1_sa_vyrovn%C3%A1_eur%C3%B3pskym_metropol%C3%A1m._Nazrite_do_Nivy_centra_(51536059094).jpg)  
[Nivy](/wiki/Nivy_Station "Nivy Station") is a mixed use complex with underground international bus station opened in 2021.  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/BRATISLAVSK%C3%9D_TERMIN%C3%81L_-_panoramio.jpg/195px-BRATISLAVSK%C3%9D_TERMIN%C3%81L_-_panoramio.jpg)](/wiki/File:BRATISLAVSK%C3%9D_TERMIN%C3%81L_-_panoramio.jpg)  
Terminal building at [Bratislava Airport](/wiki/Bratislava_Airport "Bratislava Airport") (BTS)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/2011-06-14_10-23-56_Austria_Nieder%C3%B6sterreich_Fischamend_Markt.jpg/195px-2011-06-14_10-23-56_Austria_Nieder%C3%B6sterreich_Fischamend_Markt.jpg)](/wiki/File:2011-06-14_10-23-56_Austria_Nieder%C3%B6sterreich_Fischamend_Markt.jpg)  
Bratislava is also served by the [Vienna International Airport](/wiki/Vienna_International_Airport "Vienna International Airport"), located 49 kilometres (30.4 mi) west of the city centre.

The geographical position of Bratislava in Central Europe has long made it a natural crossroads for international trade traffic.^[\[197\]](#cite_note-199)^{#cite_ref-199}

Public transport in Bratislava is managed by [Dopravný podnik Bratislava](/wiki/Dopravn%C3%BD_podnik_Bratislava "Dopravný podnik Bratislava"), a city-owned company. The transport system is known as *Mestská hromadná doprava* (MHD, Municipal Mass Transit) and employs buses, [trams](/wiki/Tram "Tram"), and [trolleybuses](/wiki/Trolleybus "Trolleybus").^[\[198\]](#cite_note-publictransportroutes-200)^ Most of the Bratislava public transport is coated in a typical color combination of red and black.{#cite_ref-publictransportroutes_200-0}

Bratislava is also part of an integrated system, *IDS BK,* connecting city public transport with other transport companies in the Bratislava region. Traveling with a single ticket is possible throughout the system network, both in Bratislava and to the nearby villages and cities, including three other districts of Senec, Malacky, and Pezinok.

As a rail hub, the city has direct connections to [Austria](/wiki/Austria "Austria"), [Hungary](/wiki/Hungary "Hungary"), the [Czech Republic](/wiki/Czech_Republic "Czech Republic"), [Poland](/wiki/Poland "Poland"), [Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany"), [Croatia](/wiki/Croatia "Croatia"), [Slovenia](/wiki/Slovenia "Slovenia") and the rest of Slovakia. [Bratislava-Petržalka railway station](/wiki/Bratislava-Petr%C5%BEalka_railway_station "Bratislava-Petržalka railway station") and [Bratislava Main station](/wiki/Bratislava_main_railway_station "Bratislava main railway station") are the principal railway stations.

Daily trains and buses from Bratislava to Vienna run multiple times every hour, with the [Wien Hbf](/wiki/Wien_Hauptbahnhof "Wien Hauptbahnhof") train station serving Bratislava as well, with more connections throughout Europe, opening possibilities for a travel to [Italy](/wiki/Italy "Italy") and [France](/wiki/France "France") with a quick change of trains in Vienna.

The main bus station (*Autobusová stanica* or *Autobusová stanica Nivy* ) is located at Mlynské Nivy, east of the city centre, and offers both bus connections to cities in Slovakia and international bus lines. A new bus station attached to a shopping mall, administration centre, and Bratislava's tallest skyscraper, Nivy Tower, was opened on the 30th of September 2021.^[\[199\]](#cite_note-201)^ The bus station lies underground and its design was inspired by airport terminals. The waiting area offers enough space and comfort to wait for the bus.{#cite_ref-201}

The motorway system provides direct access to [Brno](/wiki/Brno "Brno") in the Czech Republic, [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna") in Austria, [Budapest](/wiki/Budapest "Budapest") in Hungary, [Trnava](/wiki/Trnava "Trnava"), and other points in Slovakia. The [A6 motorway](/wiki/Nordostautobahn "Nordostautobahn") between Bratislava and [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna") was opened in November 2007.^[\[200\]](#cite_note-202)^{#cite_ref-202}

The [Port of Bratislava](/wiki/Port_of_Bratislava "Port of Bratislava") is one of the two international [river ports](/wiki/Port "Port") in Slovakia. The port provides access to the [Black Sea](/wiki/Black_Sea "Black Sea") via the Danube and to the [North Sea](/wiki/North_Sea "North Sea") through the [Rhine--Main--Danube Canal](/wiki/Rhine%E2%80%93Main%E2%80%93Danube_Canal "Rhine–Main–Danube Canal"). Additionally, tourist lines operate from Bratislava's passenger port, including routes to [Devín](/wiki/Dev%C3%ADn "Devín"), [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna"), and elsewhere. In Bratislava there are currently six bridges standing over the [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube") (ordered by the flow of the river): [Most Lafranconi](/wiki/Lafranconi_Bridge "Lafranconi Bridge") (Lafranconi Bridge), [Most SNP](/wiki/Most_Slovensk%C3%A9ho_n%C3%A1rodn%C3%A9ho_povstania "Most Slovenského národného povstania") (Bridge of the Slovak National Uprising, previously called *Nový most* or *New bridge* ) with the famous [UFO Tower](/wiki/UFO_Tower "UFO Tower"), [Starý most](/wiki/Star%C3%BD_most_(Bratislava) "Starý most (Bratislava)") (The Old Bridge), [Most Apollo](/wiki/Apollo_Bridge "Apollo Bridge") (Apollo Bridge), [Prístavný most](/wiki/Pr%C3%ADstavn%C3%BD_most "Prístavný most") (The Harbor Bridge) and Lužný most (The Floodplain bridge).

Bratislava's [M. R. Štefánik Airport](/wiki/Bratislava_Airport "Bratislava Airport") is the main [international airport](/wiki/International_airport "International airport") in Slovakia. The airport is located 9 kilometres (5.6 mi) north-east of the city centre, with fast connections served by the city public transport. It serves civil and governmental, scheduled and unscheduled domestic and international flights. The current runways support the landing for all common types of aircraft. It served 2,024,000 passengers in 2007.^[\[201\]](#cite_note-203)^ Bratislava is also served by the [Vienna International Airport](/wiki/Vienna_International_Airport "Vienna International Airport") located 49 kilometres (30.4 mi) west of the city centre. It is common for Bratislava residents to use the Vienna airport often, as it offers more variety and can be reached under 60 minutes from Bratislava with a car.{#cite_ref-203}

--------------------------------------------------

### Twin towns -- sister cities {#Twin_towns_.E2.80.93_sister_cities}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bratislava&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Twin towns – sister cities")\]

Bratislava is [twinned](/wiki/Sister_city "Sister city") with the towns and cities:
